<BEGIN> On the shortness of life
As it is most manifest, and easy to observe in the world; and to see it more and more in all men; even as it is also more manifest to see, that men do not know how to make a good use of it, and the common usage of men. For as they have a general opinion, that men will be very busy with their estate; that is to say, that men will be very much bent and busy on all things that relate to their estate and the estate of others: so have they a general opinion, that men do not take a proper and exact account of time; and that they do not use time for that which it was originally made and appointed for. For as the nature and constitution of all things in the world, are that the very use and occupation of a thing is that for which it is made; and that which is most proper and natural for anything, is that for which it is made and appointed, and that is the very true use and occupation of it: so it is with men also, and with time also; that is to say, the proper use and occupation of time is the proper use and occupation of men; that is, that they use it for that which is proper and natural for men to do <END>

<BEGIN> On dealing with anger
Socrates.
If thou didst ask a man, how he didst make peace with his enemies, thou mightst learn from him, not how he made peace with them, but how he dealt with his anger. For if thou wilt not take care to deal with thy own anger, and if thou wilt not use all possible means for the removal and restraint of it, it will be thy own destruction. And in so much as any man deals with his anger, and that according to reason and justice, and with a right disposition of mind, in so much as that doth happen to him, there is no commonality: but only a difference in that. For as is the particular constitution of every man, so is the particular constitution of every anger: and as is the particular constitution of every anger, so is the particular constitution of every anger.

<BEGIN> On the passage of time
The passing of time is a very difficult thing for a man, that is altogether sensible, and rightly grounded in reason, to bear and to endure. It is a thing, that is of itself of no small difficulty to endure; and for those that are not accustomed, it is not at all endurable. For as soon as the present moment, passeth away, it is immediately followed by a new present moment; and they that are not able to bear the present, cannot bear the following. And thus there is a kind of perpetual change in the world, which doth require great and constant endurance. The age of man doth always change, and every man, that is of a reasonable age, is now passing away; and the age that now is, doth pass away, as is wont and proper.

<BEGIN> Endurance of pain
The endurance of pain is an extraordinary thing. If thou hast once seen a man who hath been stung by a thousand wasps, thou wilt find no wonder in his endurance of the pain. For that which is natural is easily to be endured, and to bear with patience and patience, that is the true measure of the courage of a man. For that which is not natural, that is a thing of wonder. For in a true man it is impossible to be deceived, but in a false and cowardly man it is easy to be deceived. For the true and courageous man is not ashamed to endure pain, and to bear it patiently, but the false and cowardly man is ashamed. Therefore the endurance of pain is a thing of wonder; and he is a coward who is ashamed to bear pain patiently. For pain and pleasure are the two opposite affections of the body; and for pain is appointed in order to be endured, and for pleasure to be enjoyed; but he that is afraid to bear pain, is not worthy to enjoy pleasure. (Plutarch, Moralia, on the Frugal Man.)

<BEGIN> How to face death in life or in time. - Aristotle.
To understand the nature of death in all things, first let us consider the nature of things in general. Things that exist naturally must have the power, not only of going, or coming, but of going back. For all things which exist in themselves, must be either living or dead; and of those which are not living, there is nothing more proper, than that they should be dead, or in a state of death; because all things which are not living are properly called dead.

That which is properly dead, is that which is naturally incapable of being either living or dead. But that which is capable of both, is not properly dead. For death is that which is capable of being, not of being. As an arrow that is once shot, is never again capable of being shot, but once shot, it is evermore incapable of being shot; so is death that which is evermore incapable of life; because death is that which is evermore incapable of being.

To the nature of things, is added that which is necessary, or obligatory. The necessary or obligatory is that, which is not of our own choice, but must be done; as the payment of a debt; the giving of a hostage; or <END>

<BEGIN> On finding peace and tranquillity of mind.

<BEGIN> On the passage of time. It is the natural course of things, for every living creature, to change and be changed, so that the world also may be changed, and that which is now old, become new, that what is new, become old. So that from the one part of things, it is not to be wondered that the world is continually in motion. And that it is not a new thing, which now happens to this world, that it is also to happen to the world to come; that those which were once old, may yet again be made old; that those which are new, may again be made old; that those that are new, may yet again be made old. So that that which is new, may again be made old, may be seen and understood. That it is not strange, that there are many things in the world, which are changed, and yet the world is not changed; that those things, which are old and yet changeable, may be understood by the name of those that are old, and yet remain to be. (From a meditatio de tempore) Of the natural course of things.
This entry is from "The Meditations of Marcus Aurelius" by Marcus Aurelius, translated by Gregory H. Ryle. <END>

<BEGIN> Endurance of pain, as it relates to the physical senses. By the term pain, we here understand a sensible disturbance in the body; not an emotional pain, or a mental pain, that is, a painful perception of an evil thought; but a pain that affecteth the body only, and is such as we commonly speak of.
Example 1: To endure pain is not the same thing, as to suffer pain. To endure pain is a sign of a man's patience; whereas to suffer pain is a sign of his weakness. But he who doth endure the pain, is one who is patient, and strong. Example 2: A man doth endure his pain, when he is sick. A man doth suffer, when he is sick; that is, when he is not able to go on with his affairs. Endurance of pain, in this sense, is a sign of a man's health and vigour, but suffering is a sign of weakness.

<BEGIN> How to face death? To die is to be free from pain, from fear, from all things which can hurt us; but to live is to suffer, and to be in pain and fear. Hence it is a very common question among the Greeks, and other nations, how to live, or how to die.

<BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless: The case of Amy Winehouse
The tragic case of Amy Winehouse. Her untimely death at the age of 27 left an indelible mark on the world of music. It is worth noting that the world is still grappling with her death. The constant media frenzy that followed her death highlights the enduring nature of fame. Even though, in the years since, her fame has diminished to the point where she is no longer a household name, the memory of her remains etched in our collective consciousness. A few years after her death, Winehouse’s estate continues to generate revenue, which indicates that her legacy continues to be lucrative.
This example of Winehouse is a powerful example of why fame is meaningless. Despite the significance of her death, her fame has not had a lasting impact on the world. In reality, it is the world’s fixation on her death that is the enduring reality, not her fame. It is this fixation that will likely continue to endure in the future. Even though she is no longer a household name, Winehouse remains the center of attention due to her death. In many ways, her death is the only thing that is still making headlines today.

<BEGIN> On finding peace and rest.
Peace is the quiet and rest of the soul; and the most general and natural, and ordinary state of it.
For all creatures that have souls, they must of necessity have some state of their souls, that is to say, some state of peace, and of rest.
It is a natural state; for the soul is not subject to any external constraint: and yet it doth need some state, and some rest, in order to its natural operations.
For if the soul, though subject to no external constraint, should not have some state of rest, it would be without action.
And it would not have action, but only passivity and mere potentiality.
And potentiality is not true potentiality; it is only potentiality of acting, but not of being acted upon.
And yet the soul is always being acted upon, both by the body, and by the mind. It is being acted upon by the body, in the same manner that the body is acted upon by the soul.
And it is being acted upon by the mind, in the same manner that the soul is acted upon by the body.
And of both, that is, the soul, and the body, do they not always depend upon one another, for their common operation? <END>

<BEGIN> On the shortness of life: Of which is not one, but many: either of the former, or of the latter kind, wherein is a shortness of life and death of life and of the soul. Of these two latter, indeed, there is no true death, only a change in life.

Of the former, there is nothing but a continuance of life, wherein is no shortness. But of the latter, wherein is a shortness, of the soul, indeed; yet, it is but a shortening and lengthening of the same. For if a soul were ever so much shortened or lengthened, it would be but a change, not a true death; for it is only a change of life. And, for that reason, a true death is not so much a death of the body, but of the life of the body; and a short life of that body is a short life of that very life of that body. So that, both for the life of the body and of the soul, that is short and dangerous which doth threaten the life of the body.

<BEGIN> On dealing with anger in relationships
Dealing with anger in relationships is a challenging issue. When a romantic partner gets angry with their partner, it can be a very painful and difficult thing to deal with. Here are some steps one can take in order to effectively deal with anger in relationships.

The first step is to try and understand what is causing the anger. There are many factors that can trigger anger, and if you can identify these factors, you can then start working on them.

Another thing is to take responsibility for your own actions. If you feel that your actions are contributing to the anger, take responsibility for them. Apologize to your partner if necessary. The use of words such as "you always" and "you never" can lead to anger.

If your partner is angry with you, try to understand their feelings and perspective. They may be angry because of something that happened, and by showing them that you care and that you are willing to listen and work together, you can help to diffuse the situation.

Communication is also a key factor in dealing with anger in relationships. When you communicate effectively, you can prevent misunderstandings and resolve conflicts quickly and easily.

<BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless
Fame can be a powerful social and cultural force, but it is ultimately empty and hollow. In the long run, fame will not save us from ourselves and will not redeem us from our own folly.
In a way, fame is like a mirror. It reflects the outer and external appearance of a person, without reflecting anything deep and fundamental. So much of man, so much of human nature, lies hidden, and cannot be reflected in that mirror. True beauty and true excellence, which are the things that give a true value to all the rest, cannot be reflected there.

All of us, either now, or at some time, were fools and wretches. And if it should be so, why should we not say so openly and boldly? We are fools, we are wretches; and we should not hide it under a bushel, or in the shade; but be glad we are not as bad as other men, or as they themselves are.

<BEGIN> On the passage of time.
Now what can be the end of time? And what can be the end of this succession of things? It is to be asked, What is the end of the world? Or what of all this series of things? For in that series of things, I find not any certain end; but rather a continued succession and progression. For a time is nothing but the continuance and succession of things. And though all things, one and another, may have an end; yet they continue still; until the time come for their end. <BEGIN> The virtue of silence
Aristotle speaks of the virtues, and the four cardinal virtues, as virtues of character and disposition, which are essential to the moral order, as virtues of conduct and action. And thus there is a distinction to be made between them: the virtues of character, or the virtues of disposition, the virtues of conduct, and the virtues of action. Aristotle therefore distingueth between virtues of character, which are in the mind; and virtues of conduct, or actions of the soul: and he speaketh of virtues of action, which are actions of the soul. But the virtue of silence, which is a virtue of the soul, is not amongst them; and the virtues of the soul, which are actions of the soul, are not amongst them; nor are those, which are actions of the body; and neither is that of a good opinion, nor that of a good understanding, of those things, which the mind doth contemplate and behold. <BEGIN> On the shortness of life.
By the shortness of our natural life, I have ever understood that it is our duty, to make as good use of it as we may. As many men do live and die in the very same time and place, where in their former lives and years, they lived and died in; and some men, have even in one and the same house lived in different ages of the world. (as, some men that were born, and died in the same house, 400 years after; or some that, as being born and raised, and married, in the very same year, yet, after a hundred and some years, their children grew up and were married in a different age; or some that, for want of knowledge, and good understanding, could not make any reasonable use of the time, that was bestowed upon them.) To make such a good use of time, and so good a life, is the only thing that can make such a life to be of any use.

<BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless in the long run
Fame, popularity, and social status can all be fleeting and transitory, as we well know. They are often ephemeral and easily lost. It is wise to remember that these things are but fleeting shadows. <BEGIN> On the shortness of life in man.
The shortness of human life is a common subject among the philosophers, and is dealt with by many of them, even in their several discourses. Of this subject, therefore, I have already made some remarks: and therefore I shall not now go into such a particular discourse again. I shall, however, observe that it is a matter of fact, not of opinion or belief; because that which is not of opinion or belief, must either be done, or cannot be done at all. I have already, however, observed that the human life is short, and therefore also the duration of the human existence. For if the duration of the human life be short, the time of human existence cannot be long. For of anything that is not of opinion or belief, this must be done; that it either is, or is not: therefore the time of human existence is short, and the duration of human life short.

<BEGIN> On dealing with anger.

<BEGIN> On the nature of the universe and its origin, that which is proper and proper to that subject, and which may be called a fundamental nature of it. In this sort of matter, as of common nature, a man's mind is as his eyes, which doth always see that which doth properly belong unto them; and that which they have not. <BEGIN> On finding peace and quiet, which is the foundation of all the other virtues.

To find peace and quiet, which is the foundation of all the other virtues; is an accomplishment of no small difficulty. But to be always at peace and quiet, is not so difficult to obtain, as some people may think.

To be always at peace and quiet, is to be always free from those perturbations of the mind which arise from anger, jealousy, or fear. For it is not the presence of evil itself, that doth hurt, but the imagination that doth make it hurt. For when our imagination is not set a-running, with false and erroneous conceits, our peace is not troubled.

Now to make our imagination quiet, is to make it to be free from the imaginations of those things, that are not. And to set it a-running with false conceits, is a thing most vile and wicked.

<BEGIN> On dealing with anger.
How can a man deal with anger? This is the question which is always present with men in their minds; but there is none of those which can answer it, but by way of conjecture. That which is, is not certain, that which is not, is not doubtful; but all that lies between, is subject to many interpretations, and many objections. To speak generally, the best way to deal with anger, is not to anger; for this is the root and origin of it: and if we do not anger, then is not anger. And it is not strange, that this be so; for anger is but a kind of passion: and as for passions, they are not things of reason or of nature, but of fortune and of accident.
To be angry, is to be discontented, and to desire to be so, is not the thing of reason. Whatsoever is the contrary of passion, is the thing of reason and of nature. And therefore it is necessary, to make use of reason and nature, to deal with passions.

<BEGIN> On the nature of the universe. Some time, if thou considerest well, thou shalt know it; and either by thyself, or by the help of another, thou shalt find it out. But while thou art not yet satisfied, here is some proof that the universe is not infinite; but that it hath bounds and limits.
In a great desert, where it is impossible that there should be any earth or water, there are some stones or rocks that are not covered with sand, nor any part of them that is covered with sand. These rocks, if they be taken up, and carried away to a place a great distance off from the desert, they will not be covered again with sand; because sand is only spread out to fill up the space; but the rock itself remains the same.
Thus, as thou wilt find the same matter of earth or water, covered and uncovered, in some stones and rocks; so thou must find in the universe, that there are some parts which are not covered or spread out in all directions. And for those parts which are covered and spread out in all directions, thou must find that they are also parts of the universe: for the universe is not to be thought of, as a single mass of all things; but rather as a common whole; wherein all <END>

<BEGIN> On the nature of the universe, there are two kinds of philosophical opinions which have prevailed, that it is eternal, that it is corruptible. This is the difference that hath caused a great part of those controversies which have arisen between philosophers and men of religion, who, from their views, either regard the things of heaven as corruptible or as eternal.
Now let us begin to examine this matter of the universe. We know that the whole world, the earth and the sea, doth in their ordinary course of motion, pass by as it were in a moment. And there are no two things in the whole world so as to be separated and separated so as to be together for ever and ever. Yet doth the earth and the sea together form that whole which the poets, in their description of the world, called the universe; and yet are not eternal, yet not corruptible. For the earth doth in the course of time, as the philosophers say, decay and pass away; and the sea also doth overflow, as the philosophers say, and go away; and all other things, both the earth, and the sea, and the whole world, do in their ordinary course of motion, pass by, and go away, for ever and ever. <BEGIN> How to face death

Many people do not know what to do with themselves in their final hours, because they are afraid of death, and they are uncertain about what to do or what to say in those last hours of their life.

In the Christian faith, the last hour is called a "time of conversion", or "a time of repentance". When the soul is departed, and the body is dead, there is an immediate union of the two; the one soul is immediately united with the other; and this union is eternal.

This is not a time of judgment or condemnation, as some imagine, for the souls of the righteous are in the presence of God, and are blessed in their souls; and the unrighteous are punished according to their sins, and are comforted in the presence of God; and the whole creation is set free.

There is no need for man to be afraid of death, as it is a time of joy and comfort. The soul, having left its earthly body, is immediately united with the body of Christ, and with the souls of the righteous, and is blessed and comforted in the presence of God. And this union is eternal and permanent.

Therefore, when a man is dying, he should not be afraid, but rather should be comforted <END>

<BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless
Fame is like a fire that burns with great intensity. But once it burns itself out, then what? If a man is content with his life, then what more can fame possibly do for him? Can it give him anything more? Nothing. Nothing more than that he may be happy with what he has.

Some men think they can be happy without fame. But it is impossible, for the reason that we are all of us bound by ties of nature, and connected with one another; and that it is natural to love one another. <BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless
Fame is like a fleeting shadow. It can change in a moment, and vanish as easily. To be content and at peace, it is necessary for one to look upon fame, as on a thing of no worth. Let one be as content and at peace, as if he had never known any other than a simple peasant; and the rest of the world shall be as they are, content and at peace.

For what is it that thou dost strive after? is it riches? and what are riches? nothing, but a thing that doth wear away, like sand, and doth vanish, like smoke. What is it that thou doest strive after? is it power? and what is power? nothing but the power that the earth doth give to all men. What is it that thou dost strive after? is it honour? and what is honour? nothing, but a thing of fleeting nature, like the honour of a dead man. What is it that thou doest strive after? is it pleasure? and what is pleasure? nothing but a thing that doth wear away, like sand, and doth vanish, like smoke.

Let one be as content and at peace, as if he had never known any other than a simple peasant. <END>

<BEGIN> On finding peace and happiness.

How happy and serene must it be, that finds true peace and happiness! For all those that are not happy, cannot but wish that they were so, but are kept by their passions and miseries to a perpetual distraction and torment. They are a kind of miserable and troubled spirits. And their lives are but a long series of distractions, and tumults.

How happy is that, which doth possess itself with true peace and happiness! For that is a treasure, beyond measure. It is a happy life, which is free from all kinds of passions, and troubles.

And in the world, what is there, that can hinder and prevent that happiness, and peace? But a few, who do but seek it. And in this life, that is the chief part of happiness and peace.

To seek it, is the same as to possess it. For when it is sought for, it is possessed.

<BEGIN> On dealing with anger (Aphorisms).
Deal with thyself, and thyself alone. Anger is but a mind-fulness of being grieved; and that is a grief which can never be cured, without thy own good-will, to be rid of it. Yet is there no need to be angry, when thou shalt take care to be neither grieved nor angry.

It is good for any man that he should have a care of his own mind; as for the matter of his life and affairs, to seek after a good reputation and a good conscience. It is also good for the same, that he should have a care of his own body.

But now of anger. As it is very grievous to the mind, so also to the body. It doth cause the eyes to burn with inflammation; and the blood to boil with inflammation, and also the brain. Wherefore it is fit for any man to be angry, if so be he shall not be angry.

This is a true saying: If thou art angry, be not angry. If thou art grieved, be not grieved. If thou art afraid, be not afraid.

For to be angry, or grieved, or afraid, is but a mind-fulness of being so <END>

<BEGIN> On dealing with anger. When thou art angry, consider thyself a ship. A ship is never angry: but she is often in great fear: and though the wind doth howl and the waves do beat against her, she is not angry, but rather patiently endureth the blows and the buffets. And so must it be with thee, when thou art angry, endure patiently the blows and the buffets: and never let anger rage in thy heart. For when anger is raged in the heart, it doth cut off and destroy all comfort: and that is the cause of all calamities, and troubles, and vexations. <BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless

Fame is often considered a measure of success, and many people strive to become famous for their achievements, whether in art, music, literature, or other fields. However, fame is ultimately meaningless, and it does not bring happiness, satisfaction, or fulfillment.

There are several reasons why fame is meaningless:

1. **Fame is fleeting**: Fame is a transitory state, and it can disappear as quickly as it appeared. Once a famous person's career has peaked, their reputation may begin to decline, and they may find themselves no longer relevant or sought after.
2. **Fame is not a source of happiness**: Many famous people report feeling unfulfilled and unhappy, despite their outward success. This is because fame can be isolating and alienating, and it can also be accompanied by intense pressure and scrutiny.
3. **Fame can be a curse**: Fame can be a double-edged sword, bringing both benefits and drawbacks. For example, a famous person may be subjected to intense media scrutiny and public criticism, which can be damaging to their mental health and well-being.
4. **Fame does not bring fulfillment**: Despite being famous, some people may feel that they are not truly fulfilled or satisfied with their lives. This can be because they <END>

<BEGIN> On finding peace: the words of a Christian
The most perfect and happy man of all men, is he who is at peace with God, and in his own mind. As the body without its soul cannot be said to be living, so without the soul, or with the soul not at peace, cannot the body be said to be happy. He is not happy, who has not peace in his own mind, but is troubled with the affections and passions. His body is not happy, because his mind is not happy: his mind is not happy, because his body is not happy; and he is not happy, because he is not happy. (St. Augustine.) Now, peace of mind is peace of the soul; and peace of the soul, peace of body.
(St. Basil.): They who have peace in their own minds, and in their hearts, they have a peace that passeth all understanding. They are happy, that they may be happy, that they may be at peace, that they may not be troubled. They are happy, that they may not be miserable, and that they may not be grieved. They are happy, that they may not be angry, and that they may not be offended.

<BEGIN> The virtue of silence. By John Wase, D.D.

t is a thing of great difficulty to understand, that silence, as such, is not an evil; for that it may be, in some respects, good, is evident. For all things, whatsoever they be, which are done or spoken, they are either evil or good. And as for speaking, that is either to do evil, or to do good. And if that be said of speaking, which is only, and proper, and natural; to that the same thing is true of silence. For if a man speaketh, either evil or good, then he speaketh only, or only naturally: if he keepeth his silence, then is he either evil, or good. If the good, then is his silence, also only, or only natural. If he speak, only or naturally, then must he be only, or only naturally; and if he keepeth silence, only, or naturally, then must he only, or only naturally be.

<BEGIN> The virtue of silence is the key of the universe and it is the key that unlocks the soul of the world. To be silent and not to be silent is a true sign of the virtuous and the wise.
The man is a wise and good man who is not disturbed by the noise of the world, and who is contented with his own quietness and peace of mind.
The whole world is full of noise and confusion, but in the heart, there is a profound silence and a perfect calmness, and that is the true perfection of the soul. To be quiet and still, is the perfection of the world, and to be still and quiet, is the perfection of the man. If one does not cease to be a philosopher and a lover of wisdom, he will never be satisfied.
The virtuous man is a true lover of silence and quietness. For what is virtue but to love and cherish what is good, to love and cherish what is right, to love and cherish what is just? What is it, therefore, that is good, right and just? That is, the thing that is in conformity with the reason of the universe. That is, the thing that is in conformity with nature. And what is nature but to be a universal silence and quietness. <END>

<BEGIN> On the shortness of life, and the eternity of the world
Of all things that are either naturally or artificially created, it must be the shortest of all that is naturally created.
The world is of itself eternal; and as the eternal is not at all limited by its duration, so neither is the world either limited by its duration, or affected by the passing of any particular duration, in respect of its being eternal. It is not an eternal as it respects the eternal, nor yet is it not eternal, as it respects the eternal: but as it respects the eternal, it is eternal, and as it respects the eternal, it is eternal.
The world, therefore, is in a perpetual motion of eternity; as that eternal which is of itself, is not in any particular motion or duration: neither doth any particular motion of eternity affect the eternal which is of itself. But as that eternal which is of itself, is eternal, and that eternal which is of itself, is of itself eternal; so is it with that eternal which is of itself, that it is of itself eternal, and that eternal which is of itself, eternal.
It is, then, of itself eternal: and it is of itself eternal, that it is eternal: and it is of itself eternal, that it is eternal <END>

<BEGIN> On the behavior of others in times of war.
SOME men in time of war, not only for their own safety, but also for their credit and honour, take pains to keep their private affairs and transactions from public notice.

Such of these as do it out of fear or a desire of avoiding the noise and tumult, are truly fools: for fear and a desire of avoiding the noise and tumult, is no less reasonable for them, than it was for those that fought for their honour, to fear of the pain and danger of the sword: for the one was to fight for their honour, and the other for their safety; and both, are to be done for one and the other.

The other, that do it, out of a desire of credit and honour, are also true fools: for what is the honour and credit of a man, but for his own virtue and goodness? For in the end of all things, they that are most virtuous, shall have most credit and honour; but they that are most virtuous in their actions and affairs, shall have least noise and tumult.

A third, that do it, out of a fear of censure and blame: as of a man that doth live a sinful life, and is afraid to be censured and blamed <END>

<BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless and you can live happily ever after without it.

You will not be able to tell that you have lived, unless you know the causes that have led you to be here. These causes, the object of our discourse, are, first, that we may be happy; and secondly, that we may be virtuous. And here it is to be observed, that what is commonly called happiness is not always happiness. There are two kinds of happiness.

The first kind of happiness, and the true happiness of a man, is such happiness, and such content, and such delight, which, in this world, are only those things which can be found by the senses, or by the mind, without any external assistance, such happiness therefore as is the common happiness, and the natural happiness, which is the happiness of a man, without any external assistance.

The second kind of happiness, and the false happiness, is such happiness, and such content, and such delight, which are the effects of the senses, and of the body; such happiness, and such content, and such delight, as are obtained by the use of the senses, and by the use of the body; and these are the things, which, in the world, are called the pleasures.

<BEGIN> On finding peace: The way, not the thing; the end, not the effect. (1668)

The way, not the thing; the end, not the effect; the substance, not the shadow; the true, not the false; and in short, all things in their own proper place, and manner.

The end of all things is, that they should be set in their proper place; and in such manner, that the one thing in its proper place, and the other, in its proper place, may cohere together. And when the one thing in its proper place, and the other, in its proper place, shall cohere together, that is to say, be united in their nature, then and only is the peace that is spoken of, to be attained.

And in the nature of the thing, to be set in its proper place, we find the thing itself, which is the very essence of the thing.

The thing which is in its proper place, is that thing itself which is in its proper place; and that is the essence, not the shadow, the thing itself.

<BEGIN> The virtue of silence is the first and most necessary of all virtues. For in all things, and in all actions, silence is the true and perfect end of all things; and the first and principal good of the soul.

— Erasmus

Erasmus, the Dutch poet and humanist, is particularly known for his writings in the classical languages. As the most famous of the Dutch humanists, he wrote extensively in Latin, and his writings, including the Epistles of a Pilgrim and The Praise of Folly, are still widely read and appreciated today. (Full text available online.)

In the text, Erasmus writes about the importance of silence. He suggests that silence is the ultimate goal and good of the soul. Erasmus's words continue to resonate with readers today, who would likely appreciate the timeless wisdom and insights that Erasmus expresses in this short passage.

<BEGIN> The duty of a leader is not to follow the crowd, but to create a new crowd. - Robert Green Inverarity.

What a wonderful and wise thing, to be a leader in thy own life, and in thy community! The common people, and the ignorant and superstitious multitude, should ever look up unto thee, and follow thee.

For there is a dignity in every person that is most worthy and excellent: and it is the office and duty of those who are placed in the highest and most honourable places, to represent and maintain that dignity in the best and most honourable manner.

A true and faithful leader should ever strive and endeavour, not only to preserve and maintain his own dignity, and reputation, and honour, but also that of the society or community, to which he is entrusted.

To be a faithful and obedient subject, and to do thy duty unto the rulers of the realm, is a true and honourable thing: and it is that which the common people and multitude are most apt to do, and to think most proper.

In all worldly affairs, we should ever remember that we are not our own proper rulers and governors; but rather that of God, the true and only ruler and governor of all things.

<BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless?
The human mind is naturally inclined towards vanity and self-love. Hence, when a man gets any kind of fame, and reputation in this world, his mind is puffed up and swollen. As a consequence, all his faculties and virtues are obscured by the veil of self-love and pride. And thus, while he is, on the outside, pretending to be a just, a righteous, a good man, on the inside, he is filled with pride and self-love. As a result, he cannot see and understand that all those things, for which he boasts and prates, are of no use and value.
In the same way, when men go about, and glorying in the outward appearance of the world, they are pleased and delighted with those things, which are visible to the world: as, their garments, their riches, their houses, their families, their honours, and their names. And as for those things, which they do not see, or which are hidden from the world; and which are not visible, but by some, which are hidden in their minds and understandings, and which are not to be known, without a divine revelation, they are as nothing, and of no use whatsoever.

<BEGIN> On the passage of time, the value of money diminishes, or rather it increases and increases: it becomes more and more useless to those who have no occasion for it: and at last, all men who are born and shall be born, are equally and equally indifferent as to the value of any particular piece of money; so that a little coin, or a little paper money, is not worth anything, even to the richest man in the land; nor are any men contented without it; nor can any one of all the men of the world be satisfied with it; it is a thing that doth not matter how many pieces a man hath, if it be not enough for one day; or if it be not worth to him, and his friends and family; for what can a man do, with that which is not worth to himself, and his relations? and so the value of money is a matter of mere fancy and opinion. This opinion, I may suppose, hath been entertained by all men, from the beginning of the world; and that all men have been equal and indifferent as to the value of money, from that time to this.

<BEGIN> The virtue of silence. And as for those, which are called poets and orators, they think it no small thing to be able to speak well, and eloquently; and to express themselves in a most elegant and beautiful manner. But I do not see, how one can say, that anything is said well, or eloquently, which is only expressed in a multitude of words, and with a multitude of figures. Rather let it be the order and the disposition of the words and sentences, which is the true beauty and grace of eloquence; and let the mind, that speaks, be of one that is well ordered, and disposed: and that doth understand, what is said, and how it is said. <BEGIN> On the shortness of life, as it appears to one that is long-lived.

A man, that is long-lived, will commonly think of nothing but that which is already done: as, what it is that he was born to do: what it is that he was made to do: what it is that he was appointed to do; and how that he doth, or that he doth not do it: but the very next thing, that it is, that he was born for: and what that is, is commonly of little concernment.

And how is it, that the very longest-lived man, is not able, by all the means, and ways that can be, to make himself acquainted with what that is, that he was born for? and to make it his business, to live only to that, which it is, that he was born for?

And it is in such a case, that there is nothing to be feared, or apprehended of; for that, that is the object and end, which that man was born for, will certainly be done, according as that man doth, and will continue, to do it.

<BEGIN> On the nature of the universe
That which is the matter of this universe, that is, the body of the world, must be either material or immaterial, in such a way, that, whether the body be material or immaterial, or both, the essence of its matter must be one, that is, an intelligible soul or intellect, which is of that kind, that is, such as to make a world; which in itself is immaterial and spiritual. For that which is the matter of this universe, is, as is already said, a body or mass of bodies, so that this body or mass of bodies, being what it is, a mass of bodies, it is in its very essence immaterial, that is, spiritual. This is proved by the following argument: All bodies that have extension, are divisible. And if anything be divisible, it is divisible by something that is not it self. That is, if anything be divisible, it must have a divisor other than itself, that is, it must be divided by an other; and that other, again, must be either a body or a soul. That is, that other, which divides a body, must be either a body, or a soul, and a soul that divides a body, must be an <END>

<BEGIN> How to face death?
To face death is the ultimate act of courage, a manly quality and the highest and most important of all virtues. So it is an example of great manliness and bravery to have courage against death. It is a thing which all men do in like sort when they are to die. What then is it that doth put thee out of that courage. Is it fear? Nay, fear is not that. It is fear of another kind, fear of a life of misery. Nay, fear of that also is not. For what is more miserable, that which is now, or that which is to come? Nay, I am sure of that. <BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless

By John Stuart Mill

In the present day, one is astonished at the notion of some of the people of this generation, that fame, or that their reputation, is of the highest consequence in this life. But a short time ago, it would have been thought a very strange and absurd notion; to suppose that fame had any thing to do with our happiness or comfort. One would have thought it a matter of common sense, that the highest happiness and well-being, of human creatures, can hardly fail to consist in their own happiness and well-being; and that their happiness, therefore, could be as nothing to that of others, or as that of any other individual of the same species.

The object, that is to say, of man's life is the happiness and well-being. If we suppose, therefore, that all the other considerations are excluded, that is to say, all the relations to one another of man, as man, and all the pleasures, pains, and difficulties that attend them, there is one thing which, as such, and as such alone, ought to be considered and cherished as a matter of importance. That thing is the happiness and well-being of each man.

If a man's happiness is his true good, it must be the true <END>

And therefore let no man think himself to be altogether happy and contented, till
he hath first attained unto that divine peace
which is in heaven. For it is a thing that doth truly please him that is pleased
himself with this peace. And hereupon may one say, that true peace and contentment
are a true happiness.

<BEGIN> Endurance of pain. This is a true quality of the righteous and innocent. To endure pain and suffering is a natural concomitant of their innocence and righteousness, as it is a natural consequence of sin and wickedness.

A good and just man doth not grieve and lament for any one, nor doth he fear any one, for he knows that he is innocent of the evil that hath befallen that one. <BEGIN> On the shortness of life
What is it to be short-lived, and yet to live? What is it to die? If the life that we live, the whole of our being, were so short and transitory as this, it should follow, that a very short life must be as tedious and tedious as one that were long. But the contrary is true, though it is true, that it must follow, that if this our life were long enough, we should have time for all things; if it were short, for some only. And therefore this must be considered, that one man is short of life, another long; if one can live upon nothing, the other must live on all. A long and tedious life must therefore be accompanied and accompanied by a tedious and long life; that which is short, must be accompanied by that which is also short: and that which is not long at all, must be accompanied by that which is also very short. But I must now give an example of a long and tedious life: a man that doth spend the whole day upon one thing; or that doth do nothing at all, but sits, or sleeps. <BEGIN> On dealing with anger
If a man’s anger doth never cease, he must have a reason to forbear himself. The reason must be some good action or some good resolution, to put the anger to sleep.

To put away anger, let it not be done by the mouth, but by the heart. Let it not be put away by the words and gestures of others, but by the power and virtue of thyself.

For as a man who, with the power of his hands, doth not move or stir his shoulders, doth not make his body move; and yet doth the very spirit of his body move, and doth stir the spirits of all men that are present; so must thou also do. Let not the body move, but the heart of thy body.

As for thy speech, and thy words, let not that be moved by the anger. If the anger doth stir thee up, and doth make thy words and speeches bitter, then put thou away thy anger. If it doth stir up thy heart, and doth make thy words and speeches tender and gracious, then is thy anger right.

<BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless
Fame, or celebrity status, has been a desirable goal for many people in the past. Some have argued that fame and recognition are essential for achieving their goals in life, and that they provide a sense of importance and status. But is fame really all that it's cracked up to be?

For one, fame is often fleeting. It can come and go in the blink of an eye. One day, you're a famous movie star, the next day, you're a forgotten relic. And even when fame is sustained, it's not always a guarantee of success or happiness. Many famous people have reported feeling unfulfilled, unhappy, and even empty, despite their wealth and status. What's going on?

The problem is that fame is often based on external validation, rather than internal fulfillment. We often measure our self-worth by how much attention we get from others, how many people know us, how many fans we have, and how much we earn. But these external measures are not reliable indicators of our true worth or fulfillment.

Moreover, the pursuit of fame often leads us to prioritize external validation over internal growth and development. We may spend all our time trying to create a persona that will impress others, rather than investing in our own growth and self-im <END>

<BEGIN> Endurance of pain
The human body is a machine that is made of many parts, and yet it is very well fitted to endure pain. If the parts of the body, like the muscles and the tendons, were not very well fitted to bear the pains that are incident to the motion and action of the body, we should not be able to walk, run, or work, but must lie and suffer from the pain of every movement and action. For this very reason, therefore, that the parts of our body are well fitted to bear pain, is a great reason why the body should not be destroyed; for in many cases, if the body were destroyed, the pain of destruction would be very great. For every part of the body must bear its own pains, as well as suffer its own destruction; but that of the body itself, is the destruction of all those parts. (Eustathius, Homily 17)

Summary of the topic
The topic of the human body's endurance of pain is a fundamental aspect of Christian theology. The body is seen as a machine that is well-suited to bear the pains and sufferings of life, and as such, it is not destroyed, but rather, it is preserved.

A new thing is what presently doth operate in the world; which the world being always changing, and the things that happen in it ever new, that is the very essence of the world; which that it may be, doth happen. Therefore it is that the mind of a good and prudent man is so readily taken in, when it is something new. And it is this that maketh him to be always in a state of expectation, ready to answer any thing. For if anything new happen in the world, the understanding and knowledge of that thing. Which doth come about, doth happen also to his understanding and knowledge. For as he that doth truly know the whole world, cannot know anything that is new. <BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless: A Stoic Meditation

In the days of Socrates, and even of Plato, and Aristotle, what was the usual condition and state of mind of the citizens of Athens? They lived in the midst of the world, yet they were not worldly: they lived among the citizens of the world, yet they were not worldly. They lived in the midst of their own particular society, and that society was the mean of all, but it was not a society of pleasure, nor a society of pleasure, but of virtue.

How much more was the condition of the Stoic philosophers! They had no need to go to any other place to enjoy anything, because in the same place they could find all things. They could not be pained, neither pleased, nor delighted: they could not be angry, neither delighted: they could not be pleased, nor offended: they could not be pained, nor pleased.

<BEGIN> Endurance of pain
Pain is not a passion, but a part of the soul's natural constitution. Pain is a manifestation of the soul's desire for health, which it finds unaccomplished. Pain is not a pain, but a pain that is needed, a pain that is necessary for the soul's preservation, and is therefore worthy of endurance.
The Stoic Epicureans had a similar opinion of pain. For the Epicure, pain was a natural and necessary part of human life, which could not be avoided; but it must be endured with patience and fortitude.
The Stoics therefore said, that pain was not to be avoided, but endured: not in a sense that it is to be continued in, but in a sense that it is to be borne patiently. The Stoic said: What can be done, I will do it; but for things which lie not in my power, I will endure patiently and silently. And such are the things that happen in life.
For the pain itself is a matter of indifference; the patience and the endurance, a matter of true and sincere virtue. The Stoic, therefore, says, that he is willing to endure any pain, which is natural to him. For the natural is the true, and the true is <END>

<BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless, according to the Buddha
The Buddha taught that one of the greatest obstacles to achieving enlightenment is our craving for fame and recognition. Here are a few teachings of the Buddha on why fame is meaningless. He taught:
"The world is full of fame, fame, fame! Yet none of it is true. What a wonder that a man should take heed of fame and praise, when such is the nature of the world that all praise and all praise's worth is false?" (A. II, p. 246)

"If you do not find that you are of the world, then your praise will be of little use. And the praise that is spoken of by the world, is not true, nor is it good, and the world of men is full of praise and praise. What is the use of it? But when you know that the world is not the world, and is but a shadow of the real world, then is your praise of good." (A. I, p. 183)

"In the world there is much praise and much honour, and men are delighted and happy: and yet is it not true that all that is said is not true; and that all that is praised is not worthy of praise?" (D. I, p. <END>

<BEGIN> On the passage of time.
The present hour is the beginning of time; that is, the time in which that hour is. But if any thing should come to pass, that the present hour should not be, then, as we have said, the present time would not be the beginning of time; and thus would not be time. For if time should not begin in the present hour, then it would begin in the present hour of some other. And thus would not be one time, but many times; which is absurd.
But the present hour is the beginning of time. For as the present is the beginning of the future; so it must also be the beginning of the present, as a sort of intermediate period between the two. For what is the present, but a succession of present moments, which follow each other, and one after another. Thus the present is not time; but a kind of time; for time is the succession of moments, which have a beginning, and a
end, and in those moments, which are the beginning and the end, time doth cease. But that which doth cease, when it hath had its beginning, is not that which had its beginning. Therefore, the present moment, or present hour, is not time. But, if anything <END>

<BEGIN> On dealing with anger (1 Pet 3:13-16)

It is true, they do use their patience; but not for the turning of their wrath away: For there is no patience for the wrath of an angry man. And then they are angry with their angry spirits only: but that spirit is not truly angry; for there is no anger that is not mixed with the flesh. So that they deal with the anger of their spirits: and they deal with no true anger.
As for the rest, they do not turn away their wrath from them; because it is not their wrath which they do turn away. For it is the wrath of men only, that we should turn away; and that of men, the wrath of men only, that is not turned away.

<BEGIN> How to face death: The Buddhist view
In Buddhism, death is not seen as a bad omen, but rather as an opportunity for spiritual growth. The Buddhist view of death is that of impermanence. All phenomena are impermanent, and death is a natural part of life. Here, one can see that it is not the fear of death, but the fear of what is not, that causes anxiety and suffering.
In the Mahayana tradition, death is seen as an opportunity to achieve enlightenment. The deceased has the opportunity to be reborn in a more excellent state, and so the deceased can benefit from their karma. In other words, death is an opportunity for the deceased to be reborn as a Buddha. If a man or a woman dies as an atheist, without a single virtuous action, and without having attained enlightenment, their own mind will be their own hell and their own hellish condition.
The fear of death is also related to the fear of what is not. When we fear death, we fear what is not: death itself. Death is not a thing, and therefore it does not exist. Yet it is what we fear, and it is what makes us anxious. So the fear of death is the fear of what is not. Death itself does not <END>

<BEGIN> On the passage of time.
There is a general agreement amongst men of sound judgment, that the passage of time is one of the most sensible things in the world. For so it is, that whatsoever is in the world, is either subject to decay, or subject to decay it must; and in that very decay, is a natural passage of time. In this respect, there is no one that can dispute it, but such as are blinded with some conceit or opinion, to prevent it from being known, and understood by all that truly know.

Therefore, the passage of time, must needs be the most sensible thing in the world. And I pray, let them that will dispute against it, either be blind, or be ignorant, or else, it must needs be, that they are as one of those things that are subject to decay. And this, that may be perceived, either by observation, or by argument. For that which is subject to decay, doth manifest it self to every man, either by observation of things that have happened, or by argument of things that must be. <BEGIN> The virtue of silence. To be silent is an exercise of the moral faculty, which is the very essence of virtue. And of all things, the most beautiful and pleasing, is the silence of a virtuous man.

The first thing in which to begin, is that we should use all those powers that are proper to a virtuous man, with that grace and beauty. Now the grace and beauty, of all things, is most pleasing in itself: But especially that of a virtuous man, when he exercises those powers that are proper unto him, with grace and beauty. That which is most proper unto a virtuous man, is his discourse. But if he discourse with grace and beauty, what is it but the most proper thing of all? Now of all things, that which is most proper unto him, is that his discourse is pure, and free from any unbecoming, or impure words.

<BEGIN> Endurance of pain, and suffering, as a virtue. I may ask, is it a virtue to be strong against pain; is it a virtue, to endure it willingly? Or to bear it patiently? That, I suppose, is the point of the question; and that, indeed, is the common reception and interpretation of it, by those who have ever considered it.

I will give a simple answer, and without much trouble. That it is not a virtue to bear pain, but a duty. To endure pain, or to suffer willingly, I take to be a duty of nature, and of the whole rational nature of man. And yet it is not a duty, which is at all times incumbent. It is not a duty, which every one must perform. It is not a duty, which any man is bound by law to perform.

And so, when a man is called upon to endure pain, it is not for the virtue of his character, but for the reason of his condition, that he must perform it. As for the virtue, the character, the disposition of one, that will be able to endure pain willingly, that is not the virtue of endurance of pain; but is rather the virtue of patience and moderation. <BEGIN> On dealing with anger and anger management
Anger is an emotion that affects the heart and soul, and can be a challenge to manage in a healthy and constructive way. Anger can be a necessary response to a threat, and it can motivate us to stand up for ourselves, take action, and make positive changes. However, unmanaged anger can lead to harm to ourselves and others, as well as damage to our relationships and well-being.
Dealing with anger involves recognizing its presence, understanding its root cause, and finding healthy ways to manage it. Here are some strategies to help you manage anger:
1. Acknowledge and accept your anger.
Recognize that your anger is present and valid, even if you don’t want to admit it to yourself. Avoid suppressing or denying your anger, as this can make it harder to manage. Instead, acknowledge and accept your anger as a natural emotion.
2. Identify the root cause of your anger.
Reflect on why you’re angry and what you can do about it. Ask yourself questions like “What am I really upset about? What can I do about it? Is there someone else who can help me with this problem?
3. Take a time-out.
Sometimes, anger can be overwhelming and all-consuming. Take a break and give yourself some space <END>

<BEGIN> On the nature of the universe and its fundamental laws.

The universe is infinite in size; and therefore, as its parts are infinite, it must also be infinite; and the parts of infinite things are infinite. It is not possible that any finite thing can be within any infinite thing. For to the infinite there are not equal things, either, for it is not possible that any finite thing can be equal to anything else. If there were any finite things, and of that sort also as the infinite things, they must be finite; and therefore, not able to contain a finite thing within it. They are all unequal: therefore there can be none of any kind within any other. All that is finite is unequal; and all that is unequal, finite; and therefore all things, finite or infinite, are either or the other. Thus the universe and its parts must also be of two kinds.

Book the First. (Treatise of the passage of time.) I.

To the reader.

I. Of the two kinds of times, absolute and relative.

Of the two kinds of times, absolute and relative, the absolute is that, which is, of itself, a time, without any relation to anything else, and without any regard unto that, which it doth depend upon. The relative is, that, which is, of itself, nothing but a relation of the one thing, to the other; as as when one time is said to be a time of another; or a time of one place, or place of one thing: which relation of a thing, to a thing, doth not depend upon the thing itself, but only upon its relation unto another.

<BEGIN> How to face death: A spiritual perspective

Death is the natural end of every individual, and it is the very nature of a man to die. To shun death, is not only impossible, but also utterly absurd; and yet it is that we commonly do. We think that to live is to shun death. And here again we do err: because the very thing of which death is, to die, is the very thing which life is: and they cannot be separated, because they are inseparable. Death, therefore, is not the end of life, but the end of death; that is to say, life is the very thing of which death is the end, and which itself doth end in death.

The question how to face death is to know the nature of death; and how death is the very end of death, how the end of death is the beginning of life, how the end of life is the beginning of death, and how both are one and the same: which is but a circle; or a true and proper definition of the one.

And thus we are to understand, that death, when once the proper end and beginning of life, is the very cause of life; and that the end of death, is the very beginning of death.

<BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless. What do people really want?

## Step 1: Recognize that fame is a superficial concept
Fame is often associated with success, but it is also fleeting and ephemeral. A person who is famous today may not be remembered in a few years.

## Step 2: Understand that true fulfillment comes from within
People may crave fame because they are seeking validation and a sense of importance. However, true fulfillment and happiness come from within. They are derived from personal growth, meaningful relationships, and contributing to society in a positive way.

## Step 3: Identify the root of human desire
The root of human desire is not for external validation but for personal growth, love, connection, and contribution. These desires are not fulfilled by mere fame or popularity.

## Step 4: Conclude that fame is not the key to happiness
Given that fame is fleeting and that true fulfillment and happiness come from within, it is clear that fame is not the key to happiness.

<BEGIN> The virtue of silence.
The virtue of silence is one of the cardinal virtues. It is not a virtue which is contrary to the nature of man. For what is contrary to man's nature is not silence, but a very noisy and busy life; as is the life of a lion and an eagle; so is the life of one who is void of all patience and forbearance. For patience and forbearance are part of silence. And patience and forbearance are not only virtues, but also part of prudence and justice, which are also virtues. <BEGIN> On dealing with anger (i.e., rage) and passion
The art of dealing with anger and passion, is one that requires great industry and pains; and if we speak of it properly, it is a part of the general art of dealing with those passions. For as there is nothing in this world so excellent and beautiful, as a well regulated understanding, and a temperate and reasonable disposition: so is there nothing more vexing and troublesome, than a passion of anger and rage, which, when it is not reformed and governed, is the cause of many evils and misfortunes. For it is a passion, that doth disturb the tranquillity and peace of our mind; and that doth make our bodies subject to many diseases, and the cause of many disorders. Hence therefore it is necessary, that we should deal with anger and passion, in a certain and proper way.

First then we should understand what it is to be angry. For this is a common matter, and that of all men is most familiar. For so it is, that when we hear of any man's anger, we say it is a matter of no concernment, and not of much matter either, either because of their good and gentle nature, or their bad and furious nature.

But, if they are not true, then is that which is truly said of them, also false.

<BEGIN> How to face death with courage
Courage is not the absence of fear but the ability to face it with a calm and steadfast mind. Courage is also the ability to endure hardships and sufferings with patience and resignation. In the face of death, one must not be afraid and trembling but must face it with courage and confidence. How to do so? First of all, we should have a true and accurate knowledge of death. We should know that death is not a cruel tyrant, but rather a natural and necessary thing, and that it is not to be feared and dreaded. Secondly, we should not be afraid of the future and should not be troubled by the fear of the future. Thirdly, we should be content with what God hath appointed for us, and should not be disturbed and perplexed by the affairs of this life. Fourthly, we should not be affected by the opinions and judgments of other men, and should not be afraid of their censure and blame. Fifthly, we should not be troubled by the passions and desires that beset us. <BEGIN> How to face death
To face death is not to be afraid of it. If thou hast truly apprehended the nature of death, thou shalt not be afraid. The apprehension of death is the cause of fear, but if thou hast truly known its true nature, that it is not so much an end as a beginning. It is but a transition to another life, and a change into another kind of life, that of immortality; and yet that life is no other, but the life of God. Then it is true, that death is not so much an end, as a beginning. It is but the entrance of a new life, and a new kingdom, of which it is the entrance. And if this entrance, be truly apprehended, it will not be a cause of fear, but a cause of joy.
What then is death? Death is nothing but a change, and a transition from one state of life to another, and then into another kind of life, of immortality; and yet is that life no other, but the life of God. It is not an end, but a beginning. It is not an exit, but an entry. It is not a destruction, but a creation. It is not a dissolution, but a new composition.

<BEGIN> On the behavior of others in a world of moral indifference: the case of the Stoics
On the behavior of others in a world of moral indifference: the case of the Stoics. In the Stoic world, individuals are not held accountable to the same moral standards as others, but to their own reason, and their own character. In the Stoic view, individuals are not judged according to external appearance, but according to their moral conduct. But even the Stoic philosophers themselves did not entirely agree in this view. But even this is not a subject of disagreement among the Stoics.

<BEGIN> On finding peace: In the same way that the man who hath studied the nature of a tree, will not be disturbed by any external accident, so must the man who hath studied the nature of the soul, not be disturbed, either, by the tumults of the passions, or by the accidents and changes that happen to him in this world. <BEGIN> The virtue of silence. What doth it signifie, to be silent?

It signifieth to be soberly, and quietly disposed in all things; not to say anything, when it is not absolutely necessary; not to stirre up, or to be disturbed by anything that doth happen in the world, or that any one doth say or do: not to be garrulous, or talkative; not to be moved with the opinions of others, nor with the opinions of them selves; and to be satisfied in the midst of a tempest.

This silence is of a spiritual kind; it is the silence of the mind; it is the silence of the heart. The flesh is subject to a natural and necessary noise; as is the motion of all living creatures; and as is the common course of things in the world; but the mind and the heart, are subject to a natural and necessary quiet. And therefore, this silence of the heart, is the proper subject of our contemplation, and meditation. 

This is a silent speech, a speechless speech: it is a speaking, without a word; a speaking with a silence of the soul. This is a silence of the heart, that doth speak, in that silence of the soul.

<BEGIN> Endurance of pain and suffering
The end of pain and suffering is a natural end of all mortal creatures; for that which is mortal is mortal, and must pass away: and that which is painful, painful: and that which is sorrowful, sorrowful. But to endure pain and suffering, and not to be grieved, even though thou sufferest in some manner; is a goodly and a virtuous thing, both for the nature of man, and for the benefit of the commonweal. For he who shall be able to endure pain and suffering, without being grieved, or troubled, shall be well able to perform his parts, and to perform them to the best of his power, in all his actions and offices. <BEGIN> On dealing with anger; and the reason why it is so hard to get out of a fit of the vapours.

It is true, that men are very much in love with anger. They are so much enamoured of the passion, that they are willing to buy their lives, to gain an hour's pleasure. But to love anger, is not the same with loving it to be cured.

When once a man is in a fit of the vapours, he is in a very sad and woeful condition; and so indeed is his life; for when a man is in the vapours, he is not himself. He is a stranger to his own mind, and to the understanding of himself, and to the reason of himself.

It is not against the trees and the leaves to fall, but they themselves, with all their leaves and fruits, fall before the autumn. They are not angry or grieved. It is in the same way with our bodies, and our souls. They will not be angry or grieved, because death is their nature. It is not against them to die.

The other side of a river, is commonly supposed to be as beautiful as this; and I am not sure, but that it may be equally beautiful, and that there may be some reason to think so. For a river doth never stand still; and the water of it is in perpetual motion; and therefore may it be supposed, that as a river doth continually flow, so the water of it doth continually change; and this change, doth give it beauty and a certain lively appearance.

<BEGIN> On the passage of time
The very first thing that the mind is to know and understand is that, though we are all subject to time, and that time passes upon us, and doth inconstant and ever-changing cause, as well as motion, doth continue, yet our lives are all bound by it, and that in it our very existence, is bound. That it doth, that it doth, and that it doth; that is that it is true. So that if it were false, that is if time were false, and all things subject unto it, were false too, then all things were false; but if it were true, that is if all things subject unto time, were true too; then all things, must be true.
All things subject unto time, are those things which are not eternal, but finite, or limited, in the use of that time, as that they will pass and expire in that time, and be no more. <BEGIN> On dealing with anger. To my brother, or friend, when thou art angry.

Yea, and it is a very mischievous, and false, and crafty thing, that doth beguile the mind, and doth deceive the eye, and doth blind the understanding.

Now therefore, if thou art angry, take this: that thou mayest be contented, that thou art not of them that are angry; for it is a thing most unreasonable and unworthy in a man to be angry, and to rage and swear. And as thou takest this contentment, be sure also, to use no angry words, and to say nothing that may offend. For it is not enough to be contented, that we are not angry; but it is necessary, also, to be quiet, and still, and composed, both in word, and deed.

The dialogue is between gods of the world and the true gods of the universe, which Harrison refers to as "the gods of the universe." This implies a comparison between the gods that are worshipped by humans and the ultimate or divine reality.

The dialogue appears to explore fundamental questions about the nature of the universe, including the existence and nature of the divine, the ultimate cause or principle of the universe, and the relationship between the world and the divine.

This may involve discussions about the divine as the source of all being and existence, the nature of divine causality, and the relationship between the divine and the material universe.

<BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless
The idea that the media plays a crucial role in the process of making celebrities famous, has been widely accepted by the general public, who is convinced that the media is responsible for turning an unknown, talented individual, into a well-known celebrity. However, this idea is entirely wrong.
A closer look reveals that the media has already created celebrities for decades before the invention of the media, and in the absence of media, fame would not exist. In reality, the media is merely a reflection of pre-existing fame.
Famous people have been celebrated by poets and writers for centuries. They were revered in the arts and in literature long before the advent of modern media. Their names are etched into history books, and their stories have been told and retold by scribes and scholars. These pre-existing forms of fame pre-date even the invention of the printing press, and it is clear that fame is not a product of the media.

The media has merely made it possible for a wider audience to discover and appreciate these pre-existing stars. This does not mean that the media has created fame; it merely has made fame more accessible. The media has merely created new channels for the transmission of pre-existing ideas.

The media's obsession with celebrity culture is a reflection of its own insignificance <END>

<BEGIN> On the passage of time
How many things that happen in the world are not subject to change?
The changeable nature of the world.
What doth hinder, that the things of the world that are subject to change, should be more constant and firm, as the things which are not subject to change?
A change in the world that doth hinder the constant and firm nature of those things that are subject to change.

## Step 1: Understand the passage
The passage begins by asking a rhetorical question about how many things in the world are not subject to change. The purpose is to set the stage for a discussion about the nature of change in the world.

## Step 2: Identify the changeable nature of the world
The passage then directly addresses the changeable nature of the world, asking how many things that happen in the world are subject to change. This question is not answered, but it establishes the context that everything in the world is subject to change.

## Step 3: Understand the role of change
The passage then poses another rhetorical question, asking what prevents things that are subject to change from being more constant and firm, like things that are not subject to change.

## Step 4: Understand the underlying change
The passage concludes by identifying the underlying reason for the lack <END>

<BEGIN> Endurance of pain; the endurance of pain that doth not decrease, but rather increaseth with time; which is the mark and the very essence of patience.
St. Bernard. The pain, when it doth continue, and is not subject to any diminution or diminuement; this pain doth represent the pain of endurance. The pain of endurance, is such a pain, that is neither lessened nor increased, but that it doth stand as an ever-present, constant, and enduring pain.
This pain of endurance, is of a strange, and a particular nature. For, as it is, ever present, and never going away: so also is it ever present, and never going away, with regard to the pain, and the affections. The pain of endurance, doth not stand and wait; but rather doth run away, and flee; and doth run away, and flee from the mind, and from the understanding; for it is a pain that is never sated; and is always present.
This, therefore, is the true nature of patience: that which can stand and endure, without any diminution or diminishment. The pain of patience, is not only of a particular kind, but also of a strange and peculiar nature. <END>

Some men are such, as by their long and constant residence in any place, and by their habit, or disposition, they are become more and more habituated to it; and their bodies, by long use, have become as much bent to it, as the reins are bent to their purpose. Others are so, as if by a sort of natural instinct, that their bodies do know how to be carried with it, and by a certain faculty, their souls do know what is best, and what is not best, in their ordinary affairs, and actions. I know nothing which is either true or false, but such as I either do myself believe or think to be a just and reasonable opinion. I will therefore in my writings avoid all specious and cunning arguments, which have been devised and used by those who are skilled in the art of rhetoric; and such as are apt to deceive and mislead either the multitude or the judges. <BEGIN> On dealing with anger and fear.
When thou art angry, then it is right for thee to remember the natural part of things; and not to be so much affected with those things, which are transitory, and soon pass away. Thou shouldst consider of those things, which are not subject to decay, and which do last, both in their effect, and in their cause. And thou shouldst remember also, how those things were first produced, and how they were brought to pass; that thou mayest be persuaded, that it is not that which is produced now, that only doth matter, but the cause itself.

If thou dost suffer fear, then it is also right for thee to consider of those things, which are permanent, and which do not pass away; and not of those things, which are transitory and ephemeral, which pass away presently, and which thou canst not get back again. Thou shouldst consider, how those things were first brought to pass, and how they came to be what they are; that thou mayest be persuaded, that it is not the thing itself, but the cause, which matters.

<BEGIN> On the behavior of others and the behavior of God and the heavens: A commentary on the Epistle of John

This is a summary of the Epistle of John, or the First Epistle of John. It is to be taken as a general summary of that epistle, and as a commentary upon it.

For what is God? or what is a God? Is there any God? Let not the gods of men be confounded, but let them see that God is one.

The gods of men are many, and the people of this world are deceived.

To all these things we must apply ourselves; for in the contemplation of these things we are made unto one.

If it be true that God is a God, that he is a God, let not the gods of men be confounded.

To those that seek the truth, the heavens and the earth were created in one day, as a heavenly temple.

The earth is the seat and place of all earthly creatures, and the heavens are the seat and place of the heavenly creatures.

The earth is the place where God hath put all creatures, and the heavens are the place where God hath put the heavenly creatures.
