<BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless and a burden to the human heart.
Fame is a fleeting dream, an illusion, a shadow; a false show, a mere pretence. The true greatness of man, or woman, lies not in their external reputation, nor in the praise of their contemporaries, or in the admiration of their posterity. It is not for a man or a woman to be called a great man, or a great woman, only in so far as he is able to do great things. What is that? That he be a man of his word. That he be faithful and constant towards the end of his days. That he be a good and a wise provider for his own family. That he be a good and a wise provider of support and comfort for the weak and the poor. That he be a good and a faithful servant unto God.

A great man is one who is a true and faithful servant unto God, a good and a wise provider for his own family and the poor and needy. He is a true and faithful man, a good and a wise and just and equitable man. He is a man of his word, a man of his conscience, a man of his integrity.

And so forth. All these things together, are the true greatness of man. <END>

A century is a space of one hundred years; so also is a time, a space of a year. Therefore, so long as the time remains, the century cannot pass; but as the century passes, the time will pass. <BEGIN> The virtue of silence is a common feature of ancient Stoicism. The Stoic philosopher, Epictetus, once said, "They who are able to endure the sufferings and injuries of others, are not worthy to have themselves injured and offended." This quote encapsulates the Stoic idea that those who are able to endure the misfortunes of others, are more worthy of happiness, and that happiness is the reward of the virtuous. The Stoic idea that suffering and injury is an opportunity for personal growth and development is a key feature of their philosophy, and it is this idea that is central to Epictetus' quote. This quote also highlights the Stoic idea that true happiness and happiness in general is the result of living a virtuous life. The Stoic philosophy, as expressed in the quote, is centered around the idea that a person's worth and dignity come from their virtue and character, not from their external circumstances. Therefore, true happiness and happiness in general is not the result of external events, but rather from living a virtuous life and enduring the sufferings and injuries of others. <BEGIN> On the shortness of life
The shortest life, which is the same thing, as the shortest and most tenuous of a man’s constitution, is the most fitly to be represented, as that which doth consist of such a slender and delicate proportion of parts, that no more than one part, which is as it were a single fibre, can be kept together without being broken.

...And what is a single fibre, but a single fibre, or thread, that doth thread together a multitude of things, in sooth as one single thing, which is a single fibre, or thread, doth do as much, and may even do more than all the multitude of them. For by the help of this single thread, and single fibre, all things are held together. And what is more, this single fibre and thread is not so much the thing itself, as it is, as it is, that it doth thread together. And what is that which doth thread together? But that, that doth itself consist of, and is itself a, or a single one, of itself a thread, or a fibre.

...And for that reason, they are not worthy to live, that are not worthy to be made, or wrought, of one single substance, or matter <END>

<BEGIN> On dealing with anger.
Anger, though it be in the nature of a thing evil, may be just and reasonable, and for the present only: as is the case with hatred, or with fear. For though anger, as an evil, may be detestable; yet it is not unreasonable; and for the present it may be just. But as for those that are angry, it is a great evil that they do themselves suffer, that they do not remember to be angry. For though a man be angry, it is not reasonable for him to be angry; nor is it just that he should be angry: for as soon as he remembers to be angry, it is not reasonable; nor is it just; and so for evermore. For such men as these, do always forget to be angry. And the reason is, that they have not in themselves, a power and an occasion. For a man must be angry, because of something that has happened to him; or because of some thing that he himself hath done. And if he can find it in his heart to forget; and to remember, that it was not reasonable for him to be angry, then is he a man, that is wise and prudent. For he has a power over himself, to remember; <END>

Sir, you would have us suppose, that because our reason is limited, it must not be used at all; which is as absurd as to say, that because we cannot do certain things, therefore we must not do any thing. The truth of a proposition, is no more to be known by the understanding, than the nature of things; but by the understanding and observation of the whole universe. And thus we find, that there are many things in nature, which we know not of, or of, only. And because we cannot know of any thing, that is not, we know, that it is not. Thus, by the use of our reason, we can find, out of the whole universe, any truth that is, and any falsehood that is, to be excluded and rejected.

<BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless, and happiness is what truly matters

The ancient Greek poet Pindar spoke of the fleeting nature of human fame and the impermanence of the things that make up fame: “Fame, which, after it has passed, will be but a memory; and all the glory, which after that is lost, and can never be regained, is but a mere fancy and conceit.” In the same way, the Roman poet Juvenal wrote, “As for that fame, it is but a bubble, which, after a little while, will be as a bubble, and in no time shall be seen.” In the Stoic tradition, the philosopher Seneca wrote, “Fame, and all those things, which are called a glory, are but a thing of a day; for they pass away as fast as they come to hand.”

In short, all these writers agree in their opinion that fame and glory are things that pass and come to nothing; and that they can have no place in our true happiness. So also the wise men of the world. They that truly desire happiness, they will not think anything noble and excellent, which is not common, or of use, or suitable to our present circumstances, or to the happiness of our minds.

Now <END>

<BEGIN> The virtue of silence, as that which is of itself and itself alone, and not subject to anything else, is that which is most proper and proper, and to be sought after; and to speak, to do and act, to do and act well; and to do, as being a virtue and a part of the natural order of things, and to be carried out; and so to be carried out, that there be no other thing of its kind, and there be no other thing of its kind in the universe.

— Martin Luther

Let's reflect for a moment on this passage from Martin Luther. What is being said here? What is the nature of the virtue of silence?

The passage suggests that silence is a virtue of itself, that it is not subject to anything else, and that it is most proper. It implies that silence is a fundamental aspect of the natural order of things, and that it should be carried out and cultivated.

But what does it mean to cultivate silence? In our modern world, we are bombarded with stimuli all the time, from our social media feeds to our news cycles. It can be hard to know how to carve out time and space for silence. How can we cultivate the virtue of silence in a world that values productivity and constant connectedness? <END>

<BEGIN> How to face death in a healthy and positive way.
Death is an inevitable fact in life, but how we approach it can determine our own psychological and emotional well-being, even in the face of the inevitable. How can one face death in a healthy and positive way?

The way we talk about death is a very important part. If we say to ourselves and to others that death is a natural, part of the human experience, that is a positive approach. It means that it is something to be expected and accepted, and therefore does not have to cause great fear. It can also mean that we should try to prepare ourselves in some way, not to fear or dread, but to prepare, to do what we must, while we have the power and the opportunity.

To say to ourselves that death is a natural part of life is one of the most powerful things one can say, because it gives us a sense of completeness and unity, and frees us from the fear of death. To prepare for death is another one of the most powerful things one can say. To say, "I must do what is necessary while I am able, that is not an idle phrase; that is a serious and practical statement."

<BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless
Fame is a fleeting thing and can be lost by death. An example of this is the case of the ancient Greek poet Sappho. Sappho was a renowned poet in her time, and it is likely that she was widely known. However, she died young. At that time, the Greeks believed that death could be a great calamity. When they heard of her death, they mourned her loss. When she was reborn, they welcomed her again as if they had never seen her before.
In ancient Rome, a poetess named Sulpicia was also well known. When she died, the Roman poet Martial mourned her loss and wrote a eulogy in her honor. When she was reborn, he again praised her and welcomed her again as if he had never seen her before.
The Roman poet Ovid was also a great admirer of Sulpicia. When Sulpicia was reborn, Ovid wrote a poem in her honor.
The fame of a famous man or woman is meaningless when it is lost. If a great poet dies, he is forgotten, and if he were to be reborn, he would be unknown again. He is a stranger, and has not been known to anybody for many years.

<BEGIN> On the passage of time: a philosophical meditation
The universe is infinite. So are all things that have being; and as the universe, so also they have no beginning. For when one thing ceases to be, another comes in, in its place; and in like manner, of all things, one is put out, another takes up its room; as a man dies, a child is born, and a child dies, a man is born, and so on, and thus for ever.

A. C.
This chapter contains the discourse of Aristotle concerning the virtues of the mind. Virtue is the good that we must do, that is proper to our actions. There are three kinds of virtues. First, there are those that relate to the understanding: these are the virtues of the mind; these are called virtues of reason or of intellect. Secondly, there are those that relate to the will; these are called virtues of the will: which also are called virtues of pleasure. Thirdly, there are those that relate to the appetite. These are called virtues of the appetite. This is the proper nature of a man. As for the nature of man, it is a thing that is most proper and natural. Of these three kinds of virtues, that of the understanding, is the most proper. For as to the other two kinds of virtues, they are most properly and naturally connected with the understanding.
It is not so with the virtues of pleasure, which are most properly and naturally connected with the will. The will and the appetite are in the same principle. <BEGIN> How to face death with courage and composure, and how to bear the common calamities of the world with patience and constancy.

Book III.

OF THE GOODNESS OF GOD.

The only cause that can possibly make any one think of the end of his own life, is a consideration of the general and universal end of all living creatures. For we know not, what end and purpose God doth set before all the creatures, in this life and in the next. But this we can observe, that the end and purpose of all, both in this life and in the next, is that we should seek and attain that which is truly and properly good and excellent, and that we should seek that which is eternal.

The common end and purpose of all creatures, is to live a virtuous and happy life: that we should live in a way of true friendship and concord with one another, and with God; that we should live a life of obedience to God, and of righteousness; that we should live a life of truth and justice; that we should live a life of temperance and moderation; that we should live a life of patience and perseverance. For they that live otherwise, will have a life that is most miserable and wretched, both here and hereafter.

<BEGIN> Endurance of pain: some reflections on the psychological and philosophical aspects of suffering.

I. Psychological Aspects

Enduring pain requires a mental fortitude which cannot be acquired without a deep understanding of human nature.  For pain is a physical manifestation of a moral evil, and that which is evil is by nature opposed to good.  For good is that which is natural unto itself, and evil that which is natural unto another.  Pain, therefore, is a kind of natural consequence or evil effect, arising from some unnatural act of the mind, and from the abuse of some natural faculty of the soul.

In order, therefore, that this pain may be endured, we must consider the cause of it, and the nature of the pain itself.  For this, we must examine the matter itself, and its whole constitution.  We must also consider, from whence this pain cometh, whether from within, or without, and whether from the body, or from the mind.  We must also consider, what is the proper end and purpose of the pain; what is the end and purpose of the soul in the whole, and in this particular pain, what is it which is required of us in order to bear it.

<BEGIN> The virtue of silence
Silence is an excellent thing: for that it is more properly a virtue than a vice, let any one either that is well-learned, or well-witted, consider, and determine by his own judgment; for the nature of the thing is not to be disputed, but either to be received or refused according to the true nature of the thing. For indeed to say that silence is a virtue, is to say that the neglect of that which is right, and the doing of that which is wrong, is a virtue. And that is a false conceit, and a false opinion of things; because silence is not a virtue, if it be not by grace: but that it is not grace, is manifest; and therefore it is a vice, not a virtue; for to do good, is grace: and silence is the neglect of that which is good.

<BEGIN> How to face death: a historical and philosophical exploration
Death is a universal and universal truth that is inescapable. We all must ultimately face death, and the thought of it can be a source of great fear and anxiety. However, facing death in a positive and accepting manner can bring about a sense of liberation and freedom.
This book is a historical and philosophical exploration of the ways in which people have faced death and the nature of death itself. It is not a simple or straightforward discussion of death, but rather a deep and nuanced exploration of the human experience.
Throughout history, people have had different views about death, some of which have been more positive than others. In ancient Greece, for example, death was seen as a transition to a different state or realm, a place where the soul could live on after death. In contrast, in ancient Rome, death was seen as a necessary part of life, and it was often viewed as a source of liberation rather than a source of fear.
In other words, the way we die is the way we live. And yet, so many of us spend so much time thinking about our death, rather than living in the present moment. And so much of our culture, so much of our literature, and so much of our personal talk, is <END>

<BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless and what you can do instead

Fame is a fleeting and elusive dream, and those who attain it often find themselves unable to enjoy it. For they are soon beset with a multitude of people, who come from all sides to pay their respects. And if they be not very careful, they will be obliged to spend the rest of their days, in the midst of a multitude, and without any opportunity to converse freely, either with those they have already seen, or with those they have not.

The reason of this is, that fame is not the same thing with real honour, as many people suppose. Honour is a thing that is earned by action and conduct, not by reputation and report. Honour is to be earned, by the way we conduct ourselves, in the discharge of our daily duties, and the performance of our several offices; by the integrity of our words, and the sincerity of our actions.

The same with religion. Religion is not merely an outward worship, and a mere repetition of words and phrases. It is a true and living faith, which is the object of our worship, and the end of our religion.

<BEGIN> The virtue of silence. I have thought that it is a great error to think that the words spoken by a man are his true self; but to think that the silence spoken by a man is truly his self, that is a good and true saying. For it is the silence, not the words, that truly represents his nature, and the understanding and will of the man; for words are but the empty sounds of a man's mouth, and empty things: and the understanding of a man, is not expressed, but only represented; and his will, is not spoken, but only understood. (Seneca)
What does Seneca mean? Seneca means that words are meaningless. A person's nature, thoughts and intentions are all expressed through silence rather than through speech. That is to say that a person's character and understanding are only properly represented in quiet contemplation rather than through noise of words. A man's words are only empty sounds that only make noise. But his silence, that is his true self, is properly represented and truly is understood. Thus the silence is the true representation of the nature and will of a man. (St. Augustine, Contra Julianum)
What does St. Augustine mean? Augustine means that a man's thoughts and intentions are expressed through silence. <END>

<BEGIN> On the behavior of others is it impossible to do justice. But can it be truly said that justice is done, when any man shall speak and act unjustly?

## Step 1: Understand the question
The question is about the nature of justice. It is asking whether justice can truly be said to be done if someone speaks or acts unjustly.

## Step 2: Consider the definition of justice
Justice is typically defined as a state of affairs that is in accordance with the principles of what is right and good, or according to the laws and institutions of a society.

## Step 3: Think about how justice is achieved
Justice is achieved when individuals and societies act according to the principles of justice, and when the laws and institutions of a society are upheld and respected.

## Step 4: Consider the role of individual behavior
Individual behavior plays a significant role in achieving justice. However, if an individual speaks or acts unjustly, it can undermine the achievement of justice.

## Step 5: Evaluate the implications of unjust behavior
Unjust behavior can lead to a miscarriage of justice, which means that the principles of justice are not being upheld. In such a case, it is indeed impossible to do justice.

## Step 6: Consider the relationship between individual behavior and the broader <END>

<BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless.
A wise old man said to his friend: “All those things which men do in the world, which they call pleasure, profit, fame, honor, and the like, are nothing but mere things, mere matter and nothing more; which, if they be taken away, the world would not be any the worse for them, but would be quite as well and full of its former pleasures, profits, honors, and glories.”

These things are indeed but mere matter, mere substance and nothing more, and without any true power. For they are but mere names, mere sound, and they have no other true and proper essence and substance of themselves.

In sooth, all our pleasures, which we call pleasures, are but mere fancies, mere fantasies of the mind; and our honors and glories are but mere fancies and fantasies of the mind. For when a man is dead, and all his body is dissolved and dispersed, what is then become of those things which were called pleasure, honor, or glory? The mind itself is nothing. The body is nothing. The soul is nothing. All these things are nothing. But a man's thoughts are all that remain; and of those also there is nothing. And of those also, that can be said <END>

<BEGIN> The virtue of silence is not only one of the most excellent and commendable virtues, but also of the most natural and habitual, and indeed necessary, one. But to speak is natural; but to keep silence also natural; and there are as many as can speak well, as there are many as can keep silence. And therefore, since it is natural both to speak and to be silent, it is a greater virtue to keep silent than to speak; but it is not only a greater virtue, but also a more proper and more natural one; and in that case, there is no occasion of either praising or censureing either of them.

<BEGIN> On dealing with anger and fury
When thou art angry, take care to temper it not. Let not it be too high and elevated; that thou mayest afterwards be able to be more composed. A man, when angry, must not forget to temper it, lest he beget in himself a violent and furious passion: which, if it be not restrained, shall break out into open and fierce quarrels; and, in time, shall utterly corrupt his temper and mind. The first degree of anger is not so dangerous as the second and third degrees: therefore, if thou canst contain and repress the second degree of anger, thou shalt be able to contain and repress all degrees of anger; for it is not only the highest degree, that must be restrained, but the first degree also: and they that are skilled in the art of dealing with anger and fury, can contain and restrain all degrees. Take heed, therefore, of anger and fury; and be very cautious and prudent, for fear of these two. For when thou art angry, thou mayest easily be led to act according to thy anger; but when thou art in thy right and proper state, thou canst not act contrary to that. <BEGIN> How to face death?
Death is one of the mysteries that has fascinated man since time immemorial. People have had diverse ways of facing death, from a courageous acceptance of death as a natural part of life, to a desperate attempt to evade or postpone it, and sometimes even to defy death by resorting to pseudoscience and mysticism. This essay seeks to provide a brief overview of various ways people have faced death throughout history and across cultures.
From the ancient Greeks to modern times, philosophers and religious leaders have offered a range of explanations for death. In the ancient Greek world, the philosopher Aristotle saw death as a natural process of nature, in the same sense that growth is natural to animals. He wrote: “it is natural that a man should live a while; for this is the way that men should live.” ( Historia Animalium, De Parte Animali, ii. 10) The ancient Greek philosopher Plato saw death as a necessary step on the path of life. He said: “He that doth not live at all is not a living man.” (Symposium, 215 E). The Greek Stoic philosopher Epictetus also viewed death as a natural part of life. He wrote: “we are not the same in all times, neither in all <END>

Tis a wondrous thing, that the very passage and succession of times and seasons doth ceaselesslie and innumerable, pass by without ceasing: and that there is no thing, which is so frequent and perpetual, as the changing and passing on of times.

But who can speak of time without the aid of some language, or way of speaking? For if he speak, it will be in the manner of a poet, or orator: and that, to be true, is the very essence of time, to be able to be expressed in words.

And therefore, who can say, that the very thing itself, which passeth by and is gone, cannot be expressed or represented, in some way or another?

<BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless, and what’s truly important in life.

Why are people always drawn to fame? Fame can be a fleeting thing, and many people end up being forgotten years down the line. Yet people are drawn to fame like a moth to a flame.

The reason people are drawn to fame is that they are drawn to power, and they believe that fame is a means of achieving power. They believe that if they can become famous, they can get whatever they want, get ahead, and be more important.

But fame is a fleeting thing. A man who is famous now, was forgotten years ago. What he did all those years ago, was completely forgotten, and what he did last year, was forgotten too. A man who is famous, is only famous for a little while.

Wealth can be obtained quickly, but the same cannot be said of wisdom. Wisdom is the ability to distinguish right from wrong. Wisdom is the ability to think critically and logically.

Wisdom is not something that you can teach. You can only acquire it through hard work, study, and experience. It is only through these things that we can truly be wise.

Of S. Paul.

The cause of anger, may be the anger of some other man, or some other thing that doth stir the mind to anger. But to deal with anger, in such a manner, as may prevent it from being hurtful and injurious, is a thing of great difficulty; for the mind, when once enraged, is as hard as stone; and nothing can cool it down, but a more violent anger; and then again it is as hard as steel; and thus it is impossible to deal with it, either to cool it, or to prevent its being hurtful.

It is true, that the anger is not always so violent; and the mind is not so hardened. <BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless

I got tired of it after a while and looked away.

After the concert, I went to get a coffee. I saw him sitting at a table. I thought about approaching him. But then I didn't. I thought about why.

Maybe because of who he was? I'm sure he's a famous person now. I don't know. Maybe he is a famous singer or something. Whatever it was, I decided to leave him alone.

But why didn't I want to talk to him? Why did I feel uncomfortable?

I think I know. I was feeling uncomfortable because of something he had done before. I had seen the news about his scandal. He had done something bad, something that hurt people. I didn't want to talk to him because I didn't want to condone what he did.

<BEGIN> On the passage of time
From the first year of my age unto this year, I have spent forty and one years of this life. Out of all those forty-one years, I have spent twenty-five years in the practice of a surgeon. How many of those years are there now, when the surgeon doth end his days?
Answer:  The number of years is now twelve; as much as was lost in the first ten years. The twelfth of these, is added now; the rest are taken from the twentieth year unto the thirtieth. It is plain that out of those twenty years, five years are taken away: as much as the thirtieth year is before, as it is after. But the tenth of the first ten years is also taken away. That is, the first ten years are spent; five years of that time is taken away; that is, the first five years are spent; that is, the ten of the first ten years are spent; and there remaineth nothing but twelve.
This problem is to find the remainder of an equable division of any number into any other number of parts.  It is to find, either the number of the parts, the number of the things divided, or the number of the things divided. <END>

<BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless?
Fame is meaningless for the reason, that it doth not make one more wise, good, or virtuous, but doth but make one more proud, or more conceited of one’s own self. As the meanest man that lives, doth, upon a certain occasion, or by some special accident, attain to some sort of reputation: it is but for the time, it doth not give him any better understanding of the matter; it doth not make him either wiser or better, but merely doth make him more conceited.

So to be understood: that if a man do desire fame, and yet do wish to live wisely and virtuously; then the desire of fame doth oppose his desire to live wisely and virtuously. For it doth only tend to make one more conceited of himself, and doth not give one the better understanding of any matter.

Therefore, as long as we do not desire the fame of the world, we ought not to be troubled at the fame of others. And even so we ought not to be proud and conceited. For if we would be wise and virtuous; and if we would live in the right and honest way; then it doth not matter how many men there <END>

<BEGIN> On dealing with anger. (Of Cicero) [1]

To deal with anger, we ought to be of the same opinion in two things; either that anger is a natural motion, and that it is proper to have some respect for it, as for a natural affection. For even though the passion be unreasonable, it is no less natural than a reasonable affection is. And therefore we must not endeavour to extirp anger altogether, but rather to cure it, as one that is sickly. But let us not think that the physician's art hath power to remove this passion altogether.

Of anger, we have already spoken; and yet there is a great difference, how men manage and deal with anger, whether they seek to be free from it, or whether they are contented with it. For in the case of the former, there is great danger and uncertainty. But of the latter, there is no danger, but only trouble and vexation; for so much is there to be done, as to take heed of one's self, and to beware of the occasion of wrath, as of any other thing: and it is no other, but that which is proper and natural unto men; and so there is no harm in it, if only the mind be kept sober.

<BEGIN> On the nature of the universe
As to the nature of the universe, it is a subject of great doubt and uncertainty. Of the elements of the universe, it is easy to see what they are, and to which parts of the world they belong; but what can be done, as for the proper nature of the elements themselves, is a question altogether different; and one of which I shall speak hereafter.

It is a thing of great doubt, how these elements should be combined together; that is, what is the true cause and reason of their combination. Is it a matter of natural motion; or some other cause? Or is it something else which doth cause the elements to combine together? As to these, I know not what I shall say, and to such matters, I am altogether a stranger, as far as it shall be possible for me to be.

The matter that doth unite the elements together, is that they are all in a state of motion, which, as I have said, is not to be understood in an absolute sense, that is to say, it is not that they move in a circle; for such is not their proper motion; but they move, as a particle of matter, and as a part of that general body, which is called the universe; <END>

<BEGIN> How to face death.
As the only thing that is certain and eternal, is death, let us consider how we may make our lives in such a manner, as that our death may not be a punishment unto us, but an occasion of profit unto us. That is, as we change, the flesh, into the blood; so also, do we change, the blood, into the spirit. <BEGIN> How to face death in a positive and healthy way

Death is a natural part of life. Everyone will die one day. A person's attitude towards death and its approach is what really matters.

If a person can face death positively and healthily, that can lead to a very positive change in the world and make that person a happy man in the end.

What is the way of facing death positively?

The best way to face death positively and healthily is to be fully satisfied with all that has been given to us. To be fully satisfied and contented with what we have is what matters most.

If we are fully contented with all we have, then death would be the most wonderful thing that can happen. Death is the end of our suffering, it is the end of our misery.

Death is not the end of our knowledge and understanding of the world, death is not the end of our experience. We will never know, how much we really know. How much we really understand. How much we really experience.

Death is not the end of our actions, death is not the end of our works.

<BEGIN> On dealing with anger. 

Hast thou not heard that man is not angry but mad? And that those who are angry are not angry but afflicted with madness? For what is anger, but madness? For it is madness to be angry.

It is better, therefore, to consider what it is that is to be done in this case: not that the anger should be put out of the way. For the way of angering is not in the body. It is a thing that doth pass and come in; but the way of it, being in the mind, must be cured and healed. The cure of this is, not to be grieved at any thing. For if any man is grieved at any thing, and that also with a bitter sorrow and a sullen temper, he is angry.

And that the cure of this also is, not to be grieved at any thing, which I have already said: for anger is nothing else, but grieving and sullenness, or rather, sullenness itself.

<BEGIN> The duty of a leader is to serve the people. But who is to say what is best for them? A good leader must consider their well-being and happiness. But opinions are not what is true. What is true is what is best, and best is what is for the good of all. But the good of all can only be known to God, and no man knows what is for the good of all.
This argument, therefore, is not of a simple and reasonable nature; for it doth not hold. But if any man would argue thus, he must be blind indeed, or a simple fool. <BEGIN> On logic and reason.
When reason is once awakened, and a man beginneth to understand and conceive things, the knowledge of truth, the understanding of causes and effects, the true principles of the universe, and the power, efficacy, and majesty of God, are all his due. For they are the true principles and causes of all things, which by reason and knowledge are understood.
In the nature of man, there is nothing so peculiar and proper, that is, not common to many animals, as the faculty of reasoning and ratiocination. And though it be not the only faculty of the soul, yet is it so proper and proper to it, that it is hardly conceivable that the soul should ever be without it.
The power and efficacy of reason are so great, that nothing is able to stand against them, except a wicked and contrary will. A man, that is truly willing to know the truth, is so far from opposing the power and efficacy of reason, that he is able to apply and exercise it, that he may be able to discern truth from falsehood, and to follow the truth unto the end. But when the will is wicked, and contrary to reason, and does not agree with her, it doth hinder and oppose the power and efficacy of reason <END>

Why, because, without death there could be no life at all, and without succession of death, there could be no continuance of life, and therefore no life at all. <BEGIN> On finding peace
In the midst of tempests
And the whirlwind of a thousand distractions
To find stillness, to be free from all perturbation, and disturbance:
The peace of a good conscience; that peace which the law and gospel both do bring:
A true and genuine peace; that peace which the world cannot give; that peace which can only be found in the grace of the gospel.
From thence I also learned to put all my trust in God, and to seek unto God, and to call upon Him. Yea, even to say unto God, Forgive me, O my God, and forgive my sins, and give me a good conscience; that I may be at peace, and not troubled; and may not be offended by anything.

— Matthew Henry

For as many as are silent, they do it of a good mind and for the better good. And as many as do speak of them, do so not of a good mind, but either out of envy, or a desire to hinder. And as many as hear of those who are silent, they do so out of a good mind; and many others do so out of a bad mind. The former, being moved by the love and affection of those who are silent, do hear of them as it were out of charity: but the latter, being moved by their hatred, do hear of them as if by ill will. And those, that do not hear of those who are silent, they either do not know, or are altogether careless and unminded. <BEGIN> On the shortness of life
Consider all that is past, from the beginning of man; and take account of the whole time of it, and of all the things that are there; and when it shall please thee, pass the rest of it: but now for once only, take heed not of all, that is past. For what is past, that is truly past, is already done; and can by no means return again; so that we have no cause to be grieved or sorrowful about any thing, that is past: and so it will be with all those things, which are future also; but so as not yet to be. And so let us have a cheerful and pleasant spirit; and mind not that which is past, but that which is future. (Cotton, p. 13.)

— Or perhaps — not. (Cotton, p. 13.)

All the world, all human creatures, are under a general necessity of doing what is just, and right: and are subject to a general power or authority; that is to say, to a power or authority of a kind, and of a sort, that is common unto all, and that doth regulate their actions, and governs their lives, unto their very last breaths.

If we would therefore consider the nature of those things, that we do, or omit, as they are the common actions of mankind, and as they are all subject to this common power, or authority; we must consider also the power and authority, that is over those things, and over those who do them.

<BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless in life.

Does it make us wise? Does it make us kind?

A wise man, a truly wise man, does not seek after fame. For fame is a mere name, a mere label that can never satisfy. It is a mere show, a mere pretension. It is a mere thing, a mere word. It is not a thing that can do anything.

<BEGIN> On the passage of time
We see the whole world move swiftly along, and many of those things which we are wont to cherish, are speedily consumed by time and decay. They, which have a natural life, as men, or the creatures of God's creation, live in such a manner as their nature requires; but they, who are of the number of things that are born of other, are brought to the point, where their own decay begins, and in a little while, are no more.

When, therefore, a man, after a time, doth leave the world, he leaves the world which doth move; and that which he has brought about by his own act, shall soon be brought about, and shall be consumed, in the same manner. And what man soever he be, or what creature, that ever doth come into existence, is but a fleeting moment. This, then, is the passage of time.

<BEGIN> The virtue of silence is so much the same with the virtue of speaking, that some have thought that one is the same thing with the other; as if it were not the same thing to be silent, and not to be able, or unwilling; and to speak, and speak not, but be able to speak; or that the one virtue consists in this, that either to speak, or not to speak, is a thing of right and necessity.
But yet, though it be the same thing to speak and not to speak; yet is the one of the two, of greater and better use and disposition, that they should speak rather than be silent. For how long and frequently soever any man is silent, his silence is the longer and more frequent: whereas, how long and frequently soever any man speaketh, that is not his fault, and doth not speak by constraint of any thing, but by nature, and proper inclination of his mind, is that which he speaketh, both of use and of beauty.

<BEGIN> On dealing with anger
To deal with anger is to deal with a matter of a great and urgent nature; but, in a manner, to put out of mind. For anger is an angry spirit, and an angry temper, and an angry mind. To put anger out of mind, is to remove the irritation of it, and to turn the mind towards the one thing that doth belong to a peaceful and a gentle spirit: the one thing, the one true God.
By and by, thou shalt be able to bear the affronts of others, with a merry and good humour, and to answer them in a reasonable and gentle way. Thou shalt find thyself a very merry and pleasant fellow, and in all the company of men, thou shalt be the happiest and the most cheerful man of all. For anger, and wrath, and pride, are all against the rule of all reasonable and human creatures; but happiness and pleasure, and a merry spirit, are all upon the rule of them. This also is true, that if thou wilt deal with anger, as I have taught thee, thou shalt have more confidence and a more clear conscience; because all those things that are of a doubtful nature, shall be cleared up. <BEGIN> On the nature of the universe
We do not know that we live in a universe. If we do not know this, how can it be possible for us to know that we do not live in one. We must know that it is not so, and if it be so, we must also know that we do not know it. So then in either case we must know that we do not live in one. <BEGIN> How to face death with courage.

Be always mindful that the present hour is the only time thou shalt have. The fear of death, then, is but the fear of what is yet to come. Let it be, then, that it shall come soon; and that thy own end shall not be long delayed. But this is not possible: that is not in our power. But let it be thy purpose, that as soon as death shall be come unto thee, thou shalt have had the time to live, as long as is proper, and as is necessary. Or, as the Stoics would say, as long as is proper and fitting. For that is the true and proper end of every man, that he may live to his own season and time. <BEGIN> On dealing with anger. A short meditation.

How doth a man's heart ever come to be so enraged that he is not ashamed? It is for want of understanding; for they that understand not, cannot understand why their anger should be such. For it is as an unnatural action. A man is not angry when he hath time, but in such haste that he can find no time to think. He is not angry at that time, which he would have been angry of. Nay, it is not in his power to be angry at that time, because that is his own time: and that he is angry of, is another man's time, and one that is not his own.

In all men that are rationally disposed, there is an end of anger.

What is it that thou art angry about? What is that thing that thou dost bear a grudge against? Thou must understand it. If thou dost not understand, thou canst not be angry. It is not angry to be ignorant.

What is it that thou wouldst be contented with? What is that thing that thou wouldst be satisfied with? Thou must be contented with something, and satisfied with something. For thou art a rational creature.

<BEGIN> On the nature of the universe
the universe of reason and understanding.
For, as the parts of an animal, if they be all well disposed and well adjusted in their natural order; then must the whole animal itself be in that condition also; as one man in one man, and two men in two men, or more; or many men in many men, as long as they keep their natural order and constitution.
And thus is it in the universe; the whole universe of things is but a large animal, or a large machine of many parts; all of them are in a natural order; and, when they are well disposed and well adjusted in their natural order, the whole machine itself is well disposed and well adjusted.
But, alas! how much disorder and confusion doth there now remain, even amongst these parts of the universe! How many, and how many great and mighty things, doth there now remain, that doth yet hinder their natural order and constitution! How many are the causes of discord and confusion in the whole machine, that doth hinder their natural order and constitution, and how many of them doth remain, as yet unobserved, and unregarded!

<BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless in modern times

These things are of little value, and do not bring us any true happiness or satisfaction. In fact, they often do the opposite. They lead to envy and malice towards those who are not as famous. They make us proud, and that is a false pride, and it will only bring us sorrow and pain.

<BEGIN> Endurance of pain in the face of an inevitable fate
is the very essence of the Stoic nature.

— Marcus Aurelius

The Stoics were a school of philosophy based in ancient Greece and Rome, founded by Zeno of Citium (334–263 BCE). The Stoics were characterized by their rigorous skepticism. In Stoic philosophy, the universe is an ordered system of natural law and necessity. The goal is to live in harmony with that nature. A Stoic is a rational being that understands his own place in the natural order. The universe is governed by reason, and so must be man's actions and thoughts. In his actions and thoughts, he must seek the common good and the well-being of all men, and avoid everything that may hinder or hinder this. In the Stoic view of human nature, human beings have an inherent tendency to rationalize. Rational beings are not only rational, but they are also endowed with an inalienable nature. The Stoic idea of man is therefore one of reason and intellect. A Stoic must, therefore, seek to attain the highest form of intellectual power, the highest power of intellect.

— Edward Herbert, De Veritate

<BEGIN> On logic and reason.
Aristotle is called a natural philosopher. And though his particular method, and particular objects of study, may have differed from those of others, we may observe that it is always such. When Aristotle did any thing, it was done either naturally and properly, or by some certain rule, that the nature of the matter is the same; and it is according to its own proper rule, and its own proper principle. In like manner, he did things either naturally and properly, or by some certain rule, according to its own proper rule and principle. And all men, who are well educated and well instructed in the schools of Aristotle, will readily allow, that all things were done by some certain rule, and according to some certain principle, which is the principle of things natural and proper.
The matter of this discourse is, that we should observe and consider, as things of great importance, all those things, which in the nature of reason, are true and just; and all those things which in the nature of reason, are false and unjust. <BEGIN> On dealing with anger and anger related issues:
Anger is a natural feeling, but when it is not managed properly, it can cause problems in personal and professional relationships, mental health, and overall well-being. Effective management of anger is important. It involves recognizing that anger is a natural emotion and dealing with it in a constructive manner.
Understanding anger is not an easy task, but a start is made when we understand the underlying causes. It is also necessary to recognize the differences between anger, frustration, resentment, and hostility. Anger is a strong emotion characterized by an intense feeling of annoyance, displeasure, and resentment. Anger is different from frustration, resentment, and hostility. Anger is an emotion that is directly related to the stimulation of a specific stimulus that is perceived as an attack or threat. Frustration is related to a person's inability to achieve a desired goal. Resentment is related to feelings of resentment and indignation. Hostility is related to a strong sense of animosity. There are many different causes for anger.
Anger can be a source of energy or motivation for the individual. Anger can also be a source of creative inspiration and artistry.
Effective anger management requires effective communication, anger expression, relaxation, problem solving, and empathy.

In the end, as in the beginning, all things do come to their pass.

A man who hath not in his heart and understanding the true nature of the world, and the end and purpose of his own existence, and the way of his own redemption, cannot possibly be contented, and satisfied, with his present state; but must always be desirous of that, which is yet to come.

This is the natural estate and condition of every man.

<BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless, and how it can be used as a tool for good.
In a world where fame is highly coveted, many individuals seek to become famous for themselves. They want to be recognized, admired, and emulated by others. They want to be part of the spotlight, to be known, to be celebrated. But what is fame? Is it truly desirable? Or is it a hollow shell of self-importance? To answer this, let us consider a few things.
Fame is often associated with achievement. An actor, an artist, or a scientist may strive to become famous for their talents. But is it truly a desirable end? Can a person truly say that being famous is a worthy goal? I think not.
Firstly, fame can be fleeting. One day, a person may be a household name. The next day, they may be forgotten. A celebrity's popularity can be as ephemeral as a sunset. And once a person is forgotten, they are gone. For all their fame and fortune, they have not left anything behind.

Secondly, fame is a curse in itself. It brings with it a host of problems. A person who is famous is often shunned and despised by the common man. They are seen as arrogant, selfish, and <END>

As we have reason, so have we also experience, of the dangers of anger: which, in sooth, can scarce be tamed or conquered. But how shall we deal with anger? Or, in what manner shall we use it? Here is that which I shall observe and declare. In the beginning of it, do not suffer anger to be raised. If thou doest this, then only, shall anger not have power to take hold of thee. Next, in case thou art angry, and thy anger doth grow, and spread, and take root: do not suffer it to increase: for if it do, it shall not be soothed again, but will grow unto a bitter root; which shall, sooner or later, bring forth bitter fruit.

Firstly, consider, if thou art angry: what is the cause of it? If it be for the honour of thyself or another, consider this: whether it be truly worthy of thy honour, and of the honour of another. For this cause is often the occasion of anger: but if it be for the injury of another, consider whether it be a true injury: and if it be, what remedy canst thou take? or how canst thou remedy it <END>

<BEGIN> How to face death?
How to face death?
How to face death?
How to face death? (If this were the true question.) What a wonder, and a wondrous comfort, that men should be so well able, by their reason, and understanding, to conceive and imagine that death is not a separation of the soul, from the body, as that which is commonly, and superficially understood; but a change or separation of the soul and body, into other places, and different kinds of things, so as to make the whole universe a theatre of their endless change, and motion.
Hence, to speak, death is not an end of things; but the end and beginning of new things, according to that infinite and endless nature, which all things, and every thing, is a part of.

A crowd is an inferior thing to a multitude; as a multitude is inferior to a commonwealth. - Plutarch

<BEGIN> On logic and reason; and why they are more worthy of respect than imagination, and fancy.
OF all the parts of a man, that make up his whole body, some are more proper to reason of, and to be spoken of, than others. And thus we may conclude, that the understanding is the most excellent, and worthy of respect, that part of any man: For the understanding is that which doth judge and deliberate, and thereby it is that which doth determine and resolve. And by reason of its proper nature, it is the part that is most worthy of respect, and should be spoken of, and admired: For reason is that by which all things that are, are known and understood: For that which is true, is known and understood by reason: And therefore, for reason of the truth of its effects, it is that part of any man that should be the most respected, and admired of all.

<BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless, according to the ancient Stoics
According to ancient Stoic philosophy, the purpose of life is not to achieve fame, power, or wealth. Instead, the goal is to cultivate a deep sense of inner strength, wisdom, and inner peace. As Epictetus, a prominent Stoic philosopher, said:
"It is impossible for any man to be both happy and averse to what he ought to do, for as long as that aversion lasts, there is either an absence of all care, or an excess of care for things that are not capable of being done. Let no man ever think that his happiness can be without an end of action." (Discourses, I, 11) — [1]

This Stoic emphasis on inner strength, wisdom, and inner peace is a central theme in many of their writings. For example, Marcus Aurelius, a Stoic emperor, wrote in his famous book, Meditations:
"All that a man doeth in this world, either doth nothing, or it doth something either truly, or falsely; as, by doing the good, or evil; as by speaking, doing, or suffering; or that which is, not, or which doth exist; or that which doth not exist; or <END>

But is it not rather the sense that the universe is not entirely devoid of peace... But that also, what gives peace in the midst of tumult?... Is it not that which gives peace that also gives order? And so it must be. And this is that which gives peace."

From "On the Origin and Nature of the World, or the Universe" by Aniela Cronin, a Polish mystic who lived in the 18th century.

The above passage is a beautiful meditation on the nature of peace in the face of conflict and turmoil. Aniela Cronin, a Polish mystic who lived in the 18th century, reflects on the nature of peace and how it is connected to order and reason. <BEGIN> On the passage of time: An essay.
Of the passage of time.
How hath time itself been made use of! What is that which, when made use of, doth outlive all other things! What is that which, after being used once, cannot be used again, but must be made anew every day, and for every day? Time, time, time! Thou art the life of all things! Thou art the measure of all things!

Of the measure of time.
In respect of all things which are either spiritual or temporal, and whatsoever they be, whether they be spiritual, or whether they be temporal, or whether they be both, all things, are contained within the compass of time. Time, that which is without end, and without measure, is the proper and natural measure, and proportion, and number, of all things. It is that which, when things are divided, the parts of them are cut by time, and made up into a proportion; which doth make the true proportion of things.

<BEGIN> How to face death

Death is inevitable and inexorable. In his natural and common course, death is an indispensable part of nature, as necessary as birth, as certain as the day and the year, as common as the air and water that we breathe. We must not suppose that there are many men who do not at last meet with death; for death is as universal as human generation. It is impossible for man to live for ever; because it is impossible for a man to be boundless and infinite in his life. The course of human life is naturally limited. It is possible for one man to live for many years. It is not possible for one man to live for ever. In the life of the world, it is the same thing. It is possible for many men to live for many years. It is not possible for many men to live for ever. Death is a common, natural, and ordinary part of the life of the world. It is as common as the light and darkness. It is as necessary as the heat and cold. It is as natural as the day and the year.

It is not right to make death a matter of indifference and a thing that is not to be feared. We are not only bound to fear death, but we must fear death. <END>

<BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless, and why the most popular artist of all time, Elvis Presley, was a good man
Why do people care so much about things that aren't really important? Why do we value fame and fortune and celebrity status so highly?
The answer is simple. People are easily swayed and influenced, and they have an innate desire for status and power. They want to be part of the "in crowd," and they want to be admired and respected. But the problem is that this desire for status and power is based on superficial qualities like fame and celebrity. When the real substance of human existence is ignored, it is easy to become distracted from what is really important.
But what about the famous and wealthy? Do they truly appreciate the finer things in life, or are they just as shallow as the rest of us?

<BEGIN> How to face death and to overcome it.
Death is a natural part of human life. The death of one man or woman is the natural beginning of the birth of another. Death is the end of all the pains and troubles and troubles of this life. It is the beginning of a new life; of a new body; of a new soul; and of a new bliss. Now the man is a perfect man, and his happiness is complete; and this he is not only in himself, but also in his works. For, though the whole world may be full of things that are contrary to his nature, or contrary to that nature, in respect of which he is happy, yet, so long as anything that is contrary to his nature or nature in respect of which he is happy, can be removed, he is happy. A good man doth not want words, nor words to speak.

A wise man speaks little.

For words are mere sounds.

And it is not good to be a busy talker, but rather to be a busy doer.

For it is not for the tongue to give counsel.

But if for the tongue to give counsel, it is not to speak, but to hear, that is a sign of true wisdom. For he who hears only, doth hear what is true.

To be silent, and to be wise, are one and the same.

<BEGIN> Endurance of pain: The Stoics on suffering and affliction
The Stoics held that the power to endure pain or suffering was a great and important virtue. For the Stoic, pain or suffering is not a bad or evil thing in itself. On the contrary, it is an indispensable and necessary part of the good life, for pain is a necessary condition of happiness and perfection. The Stoic is not a person who is averse to pain and suffering, but is willing to endure it and even to embrace it, for he knows that it is not a part of the good life that is to be avoided, but one of the things which are necessary and proper for the good life. This is clearly seen in the history of Socrates, who endured the death of Socrates, and yet was perfectly at ease with himself. But even in cases of other kinds, the Stoic is perfectly easy with himself, for he has learned to endure every thing which may happen to him.

<BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless in modern times
Fame is fleeting, superficial, and ephemeral. The more famous one becomes, the more ephemeral and superficial one’s life becomes.
Fame, however, can be both a blessing and a curse. On one hand, it provides an opportunity to share one’s message and inspire others. On the other hand, it can also bring out the worst in people and lead them to lose their dignity.
Fame can also lead to a kind of superficiality, where people prioritize appearances over substance. A famous person may have millions of followers and admirers, but if he or she lacks substance, integrity, and character, then fame is merely a hollow shell. In this case, fame is more a curse than a blessing.
Another aspect of fame is its emptiness and shallowness. A famous person may be surrounded by admirers, but if they are superficial, then fame is merely an empty shell. This emptiness can lead to feelings of loneliness and disconnection.
Fame can also bring out the worst in people, particularly in their behavior towards others. Some may resort to arrogance and condescension, while others may resort to cruelty and malice. Fame can also bring out the worst in people’s desires, particularly in their lust for power <END>

<BEGIN> On the passage of time, what do we really know?
Our memories of things past are often obscure and confused, and may easily be distorted or altered. The events, that are recorded in history, may be either false or partly false. The causes and occasions of things, of which we have knowledge, may be either mistaken or obscure. The very fact itself, of which we have knowledge, may be doubtful or questionable.

This passage is from David Hume, in his Enquiry Concerning Human Understanding, section 13. He is arguing that our knowledge of the world and our understanding of events are always incomplete and imperfect. This is a central theme in Hume's philosophy: that our understanding is limited by our cognitive faculties and our experience, and that we can never be certain of anything. This passage is a good example of Hume's skepticism and his emphasis on the provisional nature of human knowledge. It also shows his typical style, which is formal and formalistic, with a focus on the logical and rational analysis of philosophical problems. Overall, this passage is a good example of Hume's contribution to the philosophy of science and the philosophy of knowledge. <END>

<BEGIN> The virtue of silence. If it were true that the mind was not always active, but only a part of it was, then it must be, that a part of it was sometimes silent. The silence of a part of the mind is no other than the slumber of one part of the body. In such cases, the body, though it doth slumber, is still the same; the soul is still the same. It doth not change its substance, its operation, its properties. But what is this, that doth change, that doth alter and transform its operation, and its properties, which is the nature of the mind, and of that which doth actuate and direct it? In like manner, as when the body is slumbering, yet still it is the same body that is, which is the same body that it was, it is so with the mind: that doth not change, and alter, which doth operate, and direct. What doth it change, which doth change its properties, its operation, and its substances, if not that part which doth operate, and direct? (Thomson, p. 17.) The mind doth not change, if it be silent. <BEGIN> How to face death with equanimity

But to die, as it is natural, to do as it shall please God. A true Christian may die peaceably, as a true and faithful servant of God, as such they are indeed, and must be.

From a true and faithful Christian, it is reasonable to expect, that his mind shall be satisfied and contented. The Christian religion, as it was instituted by Christ, and delivered by the Apostles, is nothing else, but the doctrine of the one true God, and the one only Savior, Jesus Christ. From hence, as the Christian religion is a true religion, it must follow, as a consequence, that he that lives a life according to the laws of God, and in the right order of his soul and body, must not only die well, but must die in peace. But he, that doth not live a life according to God’s laws, must necessarily die in confusion and discomfiture.

<BEGIN> On the passage of time, a subject which I am confident, will never be out of date. For what is it but a passage of time? that doth ever change, or change not? a thing which is, and yet passeth; and which doth not remain, but passeth. So that whatever may be said, of the life of man, that it may be long, and pleasant, and happy, so that it may be pleasant, and happy, in respect of its end, it is not the matter, which doth so much concern us. For what is it, but a passage of time, that doth carry it along? And what is it, but a passage of time, that doth take it away? So that whatever be, of the life of man, that it doth so much concern us, is it not a thing, which is not so much, but so much; or a thing, which is so much, and yet not so much.

<BEGIN> The duty of a leader is to see the problem clearly and take action. But often a leader may not see the problem clearly or may not know how to take the necessary action.
Sometimes, the problem is not a problem at all, but rather a misconception or a misunderstanding. And sometimes, a problem is not a problem at all, but rather a challenge that needs to be taken up in order to achieve something greater. Leadership is about finding and solving problems, and it requires a lot of work and effort to do so. As a leader, one must be able to analyze situations, make sound judgments, and make informed decisions. And most importantly, a leader must be able to take action and implement their decisions. <BEGIN> On logic and reason, or the art of reasoning; it is sufficient to refer to the writings of Aristotle; and as he also used to say, “that a thing is either true, or false, or neither; and that one may truly or falsely judge of it, according to the nature of its properties; and that this kind of truth or falsehood can never be in the power of any man, either truly to discern it, or falsely to judge it.” That which is either true or false, can be nothing else than this or that, or what it is. Note that this passage is not from an individual philosopher, but is attributed to Aristotle. This is because, in the 16th and 17th centuries, Aristotle was considered to be an authority and a repository of knowledge, and many of his writings had been translated and published in various editions.

<BEGIN> The virtue of silence, is, in its proper season, and under certain circumstances, both profitable and necessary. For it is not always profitable and necessary to speak. Sometimes, to be silent, is profitable and necessary. The ancient Greeks, were in the habit of praising silence as a virtue. They used the phrase, " silen[tium] est quod est adaequatum ad actionem" (silence is that which is agreeable to the action). For they considered that, as the eye must be closed, in order to preserve the sight; and the ear must be closed, in order to preserve the hearing, so also the mouth must be closed, in order to preserve the discourse. And they did not speak, as a rule, to children, as they would soon learn to speak and write themselves. And they did not speak to strangers, if it were possible, but kept themselves to themselves; that they might not disturb the rest of others, and that they might enjoy their own. For they did not desire, as any man ought to do, that which is to the common benefit and utility of all men, and which doth conduce to the glory of God.

But, as the matter stands, death is no more to be apprehended. It is a thing of the past, and nothing more. It is so long ago that it began, that now it can be nothing to thee, but as a thing that is already done and passed away. The reason of it is this, that it was but a few years ago, that thou didst first begin to live; and now that thou dost live, it is many years already that it is passed away. Thou canst not deny, that thou hast many years lived, since that thou didst first begin to live: but thou canst not deny that also thou art many years old. Now if thou hadst been many years old, thou hadst been many years dead. How then couldst thou be alive, when thou art also dead? Thus therefore, it is clear, that death is not any thing, that can be apprehended or feared, for it is not in the present, or future; but is in the past, which it is not proper to apprehend, for it is not in thy power <END>

<BEGIN> On logic and reason.
As there can be but one true logic and one true reason; and that reason of a man's own mind; I suppose there may be but one true way of reasoning, and of argumentation. For by their general agreement, they do both agree in the use of reason; and that they both are governed by one and the same natural law.

And it is most reasonable, that the very same reasoning and argumentation, which is the true way of it, should be used in all cases and occasions. For if we should use some other way in one case, or in one occasion, that would be to deviate and to wander from the true path, and to follow the true path of reason. And there can be no occasion for deviating, nor for wandering, when it is well understood, that the true way of reason is that only which is common to all men, and that which is most general and most natural. For the natural and common sense, and the natural and common reason, of the greatest part of mankind, is to seek the truth and the right, and to follow it. <BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless: A psychological analysis

Fame, by definition, is the recognition and admiration of others for one's accomplishments. It is often associated with a sense of prestige and status, and many people are driven by a desire to attain fame. However, research in psychology has shown that fame is ultimately a hollow and fleeting experience, devoid of intrinsic meaning and satisfaction.

From a psychological perspective, fame is a form of social validation that can activate the brain's reward system. When people receive praise and recognition, they experience a surge of dopamine, a neurotransmitter associated with pleasure and motivation. This can create a feedback loop, where people continue to pursue fame in order to experience the feeling of reward and satisfaction. However, this feedback loop is ultimately unsatisfying and can lead to a sense of emptiness and disconnection.

Moreover, the pressure to maintain fame can be overwhelming, and the constant scrutiny and attention can be exhausting. People may feel pressure to maintain their image, and may compromise their values and principles in order to stay in the spotlight. This can lead to a sense of burnout and disillusionment, as they struggle to maintain the illusion of fame.

In addition, the fleeting nature of fame is a significant factor. People are constantly being replaced by new celebrities and public figures, and <END>

<BEGIN> Endurance of pain
Pain, by its very nature, is an insidious and stealthy adversary. It comes upon us with little or no notice. It is as a thief, creeping in while we are sleeping, and stealing away before we are awake. It is a subtle and crafty wight, that doth not seek to do us harm, but only to do its part in its natural course, as it was made. And for what it doth, it doth but in a way that is consonant with its proper nature: it is not an enemy, but a member, and a part of the very constitution of our bodies.

We do not blame the fire for burning, or the wind for blowing; nor do we blame the rivers for flowing, or the seas for flowing; for these things are part of their nature, and are not contrary to it. Howbeit, in the case of pain, this is a point of great difficulty and perplexity. To find peace, I need to quiet the voice within me which is in tumult. If the tumults of the mind be removed, the body may be at ease; but they, that do seek to remove the turmoil of their mind, must also be at rest.

In the world, all things are in a state of flux; nothing remains constant; and yet we must seek peace.

To seek peace is a thing that requires a good understanding of ourselves and of the world. He that doth know himself well, and the nature of the world, and the constitution of the universe, can find true peace; and can make good use of such peace, as far as it can last.

The mind, that doth truly seek peace, is not troubled by the troubles of the world.

We must seek peace with ourselves; and that which doth bring us peace, that is, the Word of God, and the sacraments; and those things also which are good, and suitable for a man to do.

I find peace when I am busy at my work, and not idle; for my mind is not idle, but is occupied with the thought of God.

<BEGIN> On the passage of time
We all are born as a little time in the world and the whole time is now and we all are dead, or shall be soon, and that is it.
For, as a man's life is to his reason and understanding as his body is to his senses, and so are the parts of his body as the parts of the earth. As the parts of the earth are more numerous and more varied; so are the parts of his body more numerous and more varied; but as the parts of the earth are more numerous, yet they are not more in number and quantity; and so are the parts of a man's body; and of these also, the greater part is in the earth, the rest in the body. For a man's body, when he is dead, is not one single whole, but many; and one body is the body of another, and another is the body of another, and so is it always, until it shall return to its origin; and as it returns, so shall all that is within him also be reduced. <BEGIN> How to face death and the afterlife
It is difficult for man to come to terms with his own mortality. Many have asked why we must die. The answer is that death is part of the natural process of life. Just as flowers must eventually die, so must all living things. But we must not be afraid of death for if we are not afraid, we can live with confidence and peace of mind. If one does not fear death, what then is death? The answer is that death is simply the cessation of the breath. One cannot live without breath and therefore death is but the cessation of life. Death is not the end of life, but rather the end of a part of life. In fact, one may say that death is but an extension of life. The reason why it is so hard for us to accept the thought of death is that death is not understood. Death is not the end of the body, but rather the end of a part of the body. <BEGIN> The virtue of silence
St. Ambrose wrote: "It is a wonderful thing, that all men should be able to speak, without offending; and yet how many are there that offend, even from the very beginning, even from the very first breath of their mouth; and what can this be but that they speak much, but not well?"
In the beginning, I must confess that I was in the same state with others. I could speak much, but I did not speak well. I did speak much, but I did not speak truly; I could say many things that were not true; and I could say many things that were not kind; and many things that were not just. But in the beginning of the year, 1470, I began to see, that it was a great misfortune, that I could say many things, and yet speak no word. It is a wondrous thing, that it should be a virtue, and a thing of the highest value, that it should be, to speak a few, and to say much. <BEGIN> On dealing with anger
It is said that anger is not a pleasant thing. This is true. Yet if it is not removed, it will not be pleasant even after a long time. Therefore it is to be removed. (Folktale)

This is one of the wisdom sayings in the Buddhist scripture. The basic meaning is that when one's mind is angry, it will not be a pleasant experience after a long time. This is because a long time will have passed, but the mind has not been able to calm down and the mind is still angry.

This is why the Buddha says, "If you do not calm down your mind, then after a long time, the mind will have ceased to exist, and the consciousness will also cease to exist." The meaning is that if the mind does not calm down, it will not continue to exist for a long time.

The basic meaning of the Buddhist scripture is that, when one is angry, he should calm down, because anger will not be pleasant even after a long time. <BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless in modern times
The allure of fame in the modern age. Many are drawn to the idea of becoming famous, of achieving a level of stardom that brings with it the adoration and admiration of the masses. But in today's world, fame is a hollow and fleeting thing.

The reason for this lies in the nature of celebrity itself. In the past, a person's reputation was built on their character, their actions, and their accomplishments. A famous person was someone who had earned their place through their hard work and dedication, and was admired for their achievements and good character.

But in today's age, the concept of fame has become warped. We measure fame now by our social media following, by the number of likes and followers we have. This is a very shallow and superficial measure, and one that does not truly reflect the character or the quality of the individual.

Furthermore, fame in the modern age is often short-lived. Many people achieve a level of fame that lasts only a short time, and then they are forgotten. This is because the fleeting nature of fame means that it is only sustained by a constant stream of attention and media coverage.

In contrast, true fame and reputation is a lasting and enduring thing, built on the character and achievements of the individual <END>

<BEGIN> The virtue of silence. — Aristotle.
The more we shall suffer in the world, the more we must be diligent to keep silence, that we may not be distressed by any of those things. — Martin Luther.

The virtue of silence. — As to the virtue of silence, the truth is, that it is an easier thing for a man to speak than to think. The understanding is the greatest part of the mind; and the understanding is that which doth most easily pass over into sleep and into slumber, which are the states of the soul in its natural sleep. But if the understanding be put out of its natural state, and be set upon motion; then the soul is not only troubled, but it is also distressed: and what is distressed cannot speak. — Thomas Aquinas.

Silence is a divine operation. — Tertullian.

Silence is not only a necessary thing, but a virtue of a superior kind. For as every one must speak, yet so every one must speak also only with his proper and proper voice, so as not to offend those who are present; which is the chief part and first virtue of all that can be called silence. — Cicero.

<BEGIN> On the shortness of life, as if by the mere operation of Nature, and without the help of any man.
Of the things that happen, the most part of them happen not by any particular cause, but by the necessary operation of nature; or by some one, or some few of those causes, which happen in common to all things, as the generation of animals, or the dissolution of bodies. And it is true, that all things happen by natural necessity, or by that necessity, which is called necessary. But that is a thing, that is not the proper subject of observation and contemplation; it is the very essence and nature of things, which are to be observed. For it is not the things themselves, that are to be observed, but what in them is done; for the operation of nature is that which is to be observed. Anger is a natural human emotion that can serve a useful purpose, such as motivating us to take action to protect ourselves from harm or injustice.

However, uncontrolled anger can lead to a wide range of negative consequences, including physical illness, damaged relationships, and a lack of motivation.

To deal with anger in a healthy way, it is helpful to approach it in a mindful and intentional manner.

Mindfulness involves paying attention to our thoughts, feelings, and bodily sensations, while also being aware of our surroundings and the world around us.

Practicing mindfulness can help us to better understand and manage our anger, by becoming more aware of its origins and the emotions that drive it.

Additionally, mindfulness can help us to cultivate self-control and time management skills, by teaching us to focus our attention and prioritize our tasks.

Self-control is a key aspect of dealing with anger, as it involves the ability to regulate our emotions and avoid impulsive behaviors.

<BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless and how to truly achieve greatness in your life
