True greatness, on the other hand, is about achieving lasting fulfillment and leaving a lasting impact. Here are some reasons why fame is meaningless and how to truly achieve greatness in your life:
1. Fleeting nature of fame: Fame is fleeting and ephemeral. It can come and go quickly, leaving individuals feeling empty and unfulfilled.
2. Superficial nature of fame: Fame is superficial and doesn't measure up to one's true potential or inner greatness.
3. Damage to mental health: Fame can be damaging to a person's mental health, leading to feelings of anxiety, depression, and isolation.
4. Damage to relationships: Fame can damage relationships, both personal and professional. Individuals who become famous may find it challenging to maintain meaningful relationships due to their newfound fame.

Why is true greatness important?

True greatness is important because it allows individuals to achieve lasting fulfillment and leave a lasting impact on the world. It is about making a meaningful difference in the lives of others, rather than seeking to impress and impress.

<BEGIN> The virtue of silence is that it is the silence of all, and of those only, that are properly silent. <BEGIN> The duty of a leader is not to have an opinion of his own, but to have an opinion of those who follow him; and, in truth, the true measure of a leader’s power lies not in what he himself can do, but in what he can do by the means of those who follow him: for it is as their opinion and disposition are, that it is in the nature of leaders to lead; but if their opinion is otherwise, their leader can never be a good leader, no matter how mighty he be himself.

In this passage, John Donne expresses the idea that a leader’s true power and ability depend not on his individual abilities, but on the abilities and opinions of those who follow him. This is often referred to as the "paradigm of leadership," where the leader's role is to empower and inspire those they lead. In essence, the leader is only as good as their followers.

This concept has been applied in many different contexts, including politics, business, sports, and even personal relationships. It highlights the importance of leadership development and building a team of talented individuals who share a common goal or vision.

The book is a comprehensive philosophical and theological treatise, covering various topics including logic and reason, the nature of the soul, the immortality of the soul, the origin of the universe, the origin and generation of man, the nature of angels and beasts, the law of nature, and the government of the Christian Church.

There is a true happiness in living well. And there is a true misery in living ill. It is a true happiness, to be contented with that which is committed unto our hands, to be satisfied with our estate, to be at peace with our minds. The grace of God is the way of true happiness; the grace of God is the way of true peace. It is a true happiness to live well, to live faithfully. And it is a true misery, to live ill, to live falsely.

<BEGIN> On the passage of time.
It is a question which hath been much debated, whether the world were originally created by one, or many, and in what manner they operated. The truth of that which was said by Aristotle, that the world was created in a moment, or very shortly after, is not contradicted by the passage of time. For that which hath happened in so short a time, and in a moment, can as reasonably be said to have happened, as that which is now in course: For what is the end of that which is now in course, but that which was before? For the end and the beginning is one. That which is, is that which was; and what hath been, is that which is not; and so all things pass on to and fro. That which is now in course, is that which was in its first beginning. And the time wherein it began, is the time in which all things are, or will be, made new. It is true also, that it is but a short time, since it hath happened that it hath been thus long; and so it is true, that it is but a short time, since it hath happened that it hath been so long. Now, thou mayest be angry, and yet thou mayest yet be justifiable in thy anger. For anger, though it is a passion, is not so improper. For in a good cause and good right, is it not reasonable and justifiable to be angry? But in a bad cause and a bad right, it is most unreasonable and unjustifiable. For to be angry without a good cause is to be angry in vain.

<BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless
Fame is a hollow, fleeting thing. It's a social phenomenon that weaves a complex web of psychological and social factors. However, it has no lasting value. When we get famous, we lose ourselves, and our sense of self disappears. Our relationships deteriorate. We are forced to be constantly in the public eye, to be on our guard at all times, to be constantly looking over our shoulders, and to be always "on." And this is a terrible way to live, to be constantly "on" and to be under the pressure of constant scrutiny.

But the thing is, we're not as unique as we think. We all have the same desires and fears. And when we try to rise above these things and become famous, we are doing precisely the same thing. We are seeking the same things that we all seek: love, happiness, meaning, and fulfillment. And it's this that makes fame a hollow thing. For fame is merely a symbol of our desire for love, happiness, meaning, and fulfillment.

And when we try to find these things outside of ourselves, as if they were located in something else, we miss the fact that they are located inside of us. We are not made to live our lives in a world where we <END>

<BEGIN> On the shortness of life: an exposition, according to the Aristotelian way: or, The natural constitution, of a human understanding. Whose beginning is to be found, and whose end: the nature of the soul: and the very essence of all things, according to the definition of Aristotle.

(Anon.)

What is life, say you? The common multitude may say it is the breath, and the breath, the breath. And it may be that they have spoken right. But that we may know, we must look further. The breath is but the wind, and the wind is but the air; and the air, a mass of matter, void of form, and without figure. In what manner, therefore, must it be, that this air or mass of matter, or wind, should constitute the very essence of life?

This question may seem trivial, or but of little importance, to a common man. But it is of the greatest importance, to him that seeketh to understand the nature of things; and to him that wouldst know, what is the essence of life.

<BEGIN> On dealing with anger (1) (c 2).
One would naturally suppose, that the man that is angry is better than he who is not angry; for the man that is angry, hath a passion so common among mankind; and such as every one doth feel and know. But, 0, that which doth move this common passion, doth move the particular one, with a particular passion; and not with the common one. A man, that is angry, is moved by a particular passion; but a man, that is not angry, is not moved by it at all. And this is the first rule, how one ought to deal with anger; namely, not to be moved by any thing, which doth move any one else. If thou be angry at another, take heed, thou shalt be angry at thyself; and if thou be not angry, take heed, thou shalt be angry, if any one else be angry at thee. But it is not to be understood, as if thou wert to be angry, if any one else were angry at thee; but this only, that thou wert to be angry at thyself. And this is the second rule; namely, that one doth not get angry, unless it be with himself <END>

<BEGIN> How to face death: The way of the Stoics.
Stoicism is an ancient Greek philosophy that emphasizes reason, self-control, and indifference to external events. The Stoics were concerned with the proper way of living. This involved a constant exercise of the understanding, a self-examination, and a living of such a life as might lead to death or retirement with honour.
Death is an opportunity, a way to be set free from a world that is full of troubles, full of envy, full of hatred, full of lust, and full of many other evils.
The fear of death is a mere dream. He that can apprehend death with equanimity and temperance, that can see the good that may follow, is able to make himself and others happy.
The Stoics did not wish to avoid death, but to meet with it in the most dignified and manly way. For it is written, That men in ancient times were not afraid of death. (Acts i. 2).
To live as the Stoics do, is to live the life of man, who is a part of the universe; to live the life of one that is governed by the reason of the universe. For to live the life of man is not to live in vain, but to <END>

For, in matters of opinion, no man ever can be ignorant; and in matters of fact, no man ever can be mistaken; for they are both things of absolute and universal truth. <BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless?
Fame is a mere noise in the world. What is fame, but a fleeting fancy and an empty honour? It is but a brief interval, and soon is forgot. And though it doth make men proud, and doth bring many unto a higher estate, it is but a temporary and fleeting thing, and of no true value. The true honour of any man, is that which cometh of his own actions, and doth arise from his own merits. To be truly great, is not to be called great, but to be truly worthy of such a name. That is the proper use and end of a great man, to be great for himself and for his own actions, not for the mere praise and commendation of others.

— Matthew Henry

<BEGIN> On finding peace with the inevitability of death
In our common speech, men often say and do things that can only be understood as having a deep meaning and significance, for which they must use many and varied arguments. But is not that also true of the whole of nature, and of the course of the world? Must it not be governed by the same rules and principles which are observed in the affairs of men? For what is death to us, but to be separated from our souls; and what is life to us but to be together with our souls? And how can this separation be avoided? Either we must live forever, and so be united with our souls in this life, or else we must be separated from them hereafter, as from a part of ourselves.

Happiness is that of the soul, not the body. A happy life is that wherein the soul is happy; and this is that which is true happiness.

<BEGIN> On the passage of time.
Some have thought, that as men's bodies were subject to decay, and as their bodies were subject to death: that, therefore, their souls must also subject to decay and death. But it is not so; because it is not the nature of the soul, to pass into non-existence, or to cease to be: it is, however, not so that it cannot continue, but for ever, and for eternity, and for ever. For the soul, which is the true self of man, is a spirit, or a divine. For that which is spirit, and divine, cannot be subject, or subject to decay. For if the soul, were subject, or subject to decay: then must it, also, be subject, and subject, to death; for a spirit, is, indeed, not subject to decay; but to the power and dominion of God; and is subject only, to the power and dominion, of the divine and eternal Spirit of God; that is, to that spirit, which is, and that which is eternal: and that which is eternal, and that which is eternal, must also, be subject, to no other power, or dominion, than to that of the divine and eternal Spirit of God, <END>

<BEGIN> The virtue of silence is very much to be wished, and endeavored after; because it is a thing both agreeable and profitable unto a man. To keep silence, and not to speak much, is the natural disposition of a wise man. But to be silent and mute, and to keep silence only in the matter of truth, and not to be silent and mute in any other matter, is a thing to be feared and avoided.
To speak and to keep silence are two things, so different, that they are hardly to be compared; for it is one thing to speak out of love, and another to speak out of hatred; and it is one thing to speak out of wisdom, and another to speak out of folly. To speak out of love, is a most agreeable thing: for in that also is a part of the body, and in that also is the breath and voice of man; and as all living creatures have the power to speak, so has man also that power. Therefore, to speak out of love, and to keep silent, is most agreeable and most natural unto man.
To speak out of love, and to speak out of hatred, is not only very different, and most contrary, but also one of them is more agreeable unto man than the <END>

<BEGIN> Endurance of pain or suffering.
Endurance is a hard thing, both in itself and in respect to its effect; it is hard, both, first, because the pain itself is hard; and secondly, because, as long as it lasts, there is a continuation of the pain. Of such a nature are those sufferings, which are called continual, perpetual, and infinite sufferings; as innumerable and eternal pain, as well as such as are called, by the name of torment, and such, as the pangs of the worm. These, then, are such, as that, for the time they are used, the pain itself, is the greatest part of it; but for the time of the pain, that is to say, how long it doth continue, is the greatest part of it.
To the pain itself is added another pain, of a very different sort, and more bitter than the former. The one is a pain of the body, the other is a pain of the mind. The one, indeed, is of a kind, and kindred with the pain of the body; it is the pain of being wounded. The other, is not of that kind, it is a pain of another sort. It is, a pain of being <END>

<BEGIN> On the nature of the universe, and the things which are contained in it, with a dialogue between three philosophers. This dialogue, or rather the three philosophers themselves, is a faithful picture, that we may take, of the nature of the world. The first philosopher, or the world, is the sun; the second, the moon; and the third, the earth.
That which is in common, to all the celestial bodies, is, their natural constitution, and the natural constitution of their particles, that is, their elemental nature; that is to say, the earth, air, and water.
The earth is the matter of the earth, that is to say, of the earth itself: the air is the matter of the air; and the water the matter of the water. The earth being earth itself, is by nature earth itself; and the air air itself; and the water water itself. It is then, by this natural constitution of their particles, that these three, are the three material parts of the whole world.
In this also, is to be noted, the particular nature of each, and its difference from that which is common. That the earth, in particular, is the material, of the earth, is so by reason of its constitution, that is, of its being earth <END>

<BEGIN> How to face death
The way to face death is to know, that thou dost die by a natural and proper decay of thy natural body. Thou art not slain by a violent hand, but by the natural course of that very life that is in thee; which is but a proper instrument, and an instrument of the great God, that is the Author and Saviour of all men.

Consider, that death is not any one thing, but a collection of many things; as a violent death, an unnatural death, a sudden death, and a violent death by a stroke.

If thou wouldst not be slain by any one of those, consider thyself well, and in good health; if not, seek unto thy physician and apothecary for a remedy, and for a medicine against death and death's sting.

If it happen, that thou shouldst die by a violent hand, as in war, or by some accident; consider the same of the death of the many, for as many men die by a violent hand, as by a natural death; and for as many are slain, as are slain by the plague. For there is as much slaughter, and as much killing, in the plague, and in war, as there is in any other thing whatsoever. But thou <END>

<BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless.
Fame is a thing that is both wondrous and pitiful. A man that is famous is always in the presence of multitudes; yet his fame doth not so much as comfort or benefit him. For though fame is the common fame of all mankind, and the common opinion of all men, which doth follow their own opinions, and their own fancies; and though it be a fame of a very great and excellent sort; yet is it as common to any man as it were a breath, or a sound; and therefore doth it afford him no comfort or benefit.

Therefore, as for a man, when he is famous, he is like a bird that is gilded with gold and precious stones, and yet doth he find it not so precious, as his own feathers are; and though it doth bring him many compliments, yet it doth not so much as bring him comfort: For he is not only gilded with gold and precious stones, but he is also gilded with flattery; but for all that he doth not so much as find it pleasant.

And therefore, if a man be famous, he should be contented with a private life. And as for all that which doth make him famous, as <END>

<BEGIN> On finding peace with the universe in its current state

To him who in the universe, or any one particular universe, finds peace, he shall find peace. For how can that man, who doth seek for peace, or find it, if there be anything that doth disturb the rest of the universe? For in all the parts of the universe, all is in harmony, and all things do agree in themselves: and there is not one part of it, that doth not contain, or produce all the rest.

To him also, that in his particular self, he doth find peace and rest, he shall find it elsewhere also. For that self of his, which he doth call his, is but a shadow or a copy, of that, which is truly himself. He that doth truly find rest and peace, is he that is truly his own self. He is he, that is not distracted, nor divided from himself. And he shall not find rest, if he be troubled with any false or false appearances.

<BEGIN> On dealing with anger: what can we say?

One can say nothing more, but a brief exhortation. Take heed, and be not unmindful. Remember that every man that is angry, is a man of evil disposition; that those who do not strive to be composed, are more likely to be angry, than those who do. Let every one who doth strive to be composed, use all the means which are in his power: not only to keep a secret, and to do nothing that may stir up wrath and indignation in others; but also to keep his own heart and mind from anger; and, if it doth happen, to seek peace as soon as possible, and to strive for it, rather than for wrath and anger. For if wrath and anger be a thing that doth happen unto a man, it is much better to be in peace, than in wrath or anger. And it is much better to be in a state of peace, than in a state of wrath or anger, for it is better for a man to be in a state of peace, than in a state of wrath or anger; for then will he have time to seek peace; and to keep a secret. And it is much better to be in a state of peace, <END>

<BEGIN> The duty of a leader is to encourage their people. When a leader is present in a community, he should make sure to encourage the people of that community by giving them the freedom to express their opinions. There are many types of leaders, each with their unique personality and methods of leadership.
Some of the qualities of a good leader include honesty, integrity, transparency, accountability, fairness, justice, courage, patience, and humility. A leader should always be willing to listen, to learn from others, and to admit when they are wrong. A good leader is a good teacher. The leader should encourage their followers to do the same to them.
The great leader, Abraham Lincoln, was known for his honesty, integrity, and fairness. He always stood by his principles, never backed away from them. He also gave his people the freedom to express their opinions and made sure that they were able to live their lives with dignity and respect.
Another great leader was Nelson Mandela. Mandela was a black African who fought against the white domination of his people. He spent 27 years in prison and then became the leader of his people, bringing about a new era of peace and harmony.

<BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless
Fame is a thing most fleeting: as the seasons. For now the world is full of them; and all of them shall soon be no more. But when those shall be gone that are now alive, what shall remain, as the substance of their fame? That also shall be soon dissolved. For if that be destroyed which gave them their fame, their fame is destroyed also; or at the most it is only preserved to be told of in the memory of the world.

I will be a man that shall be forgotten.

It is the duty of a man of letters to be always seeking out of that which he shall be told of; and to remember it: but it must not be for the sake of seeking of it, nor for the sake of remembering it, but rather that he may the better forget it, and to have the time to tell it again when he shall have had a good opportunity.

That which is true, is that which is spoken of as a true thing. But that which is spoken of as a true thing, is not that which is truly true.

<BEGIN> On the passage of time. Meditationes mortis.
In the spring, the air is sweet with the perfume of flowers. But after that, the trees fall off, the flowers wither, and the air becomes thick and heavy with the smell of decay; the wind blows strong, and it is said to have the sting of the winter. As, therefore, we may speak of death in the spring, so we must speak of death in the winter; that it may be known unto all, that the life of man is but a span, and that it doth end as soon as it beginnes.

Is it not, that they have not enough reason?  They are all capable of reason; for all men are naturally so, and all capable of virtue. For to live, is nothing to a man that doth not consider his death: as death, is nothing but a part of the whole life that is to pass and pass away. As long as we live, we must live well; but when we have once gone out, all things are ended. Let us then learn to make our lives as agreeable to God, as any life can be: and to make our dying, as agreeable to God, as our living ever was.

<BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless
In the 1980s, I became involved with the punk rock movement. It was a time of great upheaval, rebellion and experimentation in music and fashion. As a result, I was exposed to a lot of young people who were deeply passionate about the scene. Many were driven by a desire to be a part of a subculture, a way of life and a sense of community.
But for some, the pursuit of fame in the music scene became a major goal. Some started writing songs with the intention of getting noticed by record companies, or by being discovered at a gig, so they could get signed. This is when fame began to take on a different form. The motivation that drove so many of them to get noticed was not out of a genuine desire to do something meaningful or to make a difference in the world. For some it was to become famous. And that, I believe, is why fame can be meaningless.
Fame has always been a driving force. It has always been a key motivator for many. Many people have set their sights on achieving fame and fortune. <BEGIN> Endurance of pain: The importance of perseverance in the face of suffering
Endurance of pain is a highly valued trait in many religious and philosophical traditions. It is seen as a way of demonstrating one’s faith, commitment, and character in the face of suffering. In the context of Christian theology, the endurance of pain is often associated with martyrdom, the ultimate sacrifice of Christ, and the self-denial of saints. However, it can also refer to the everyday suffering that people face as a result of natural disasters, accidents, illnesses, and other hardships.

In the Buddhist tradition, endurance of pain is one of the key components of the Eightfold Path, and is seen as a way of cultivating mindfulness, concentration, and wisdom. The Buddhist concept of suffering, or dukkha, is an inherent part of life, and is not something that can be eliminated. Rather, it is seen as an opportunity for spiritual growth and transformation.

From a secular perspective, endurance of pain is often seen as a sign of strength and resilience. People who are able to persevere through difficult situations are often viewed as more capable and admirable. This perspective is reflected in the popular saying, "When life gives you lemons, make lemonade."

<BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless
Fame is an empty word, an empty thing. Fame, as such, is nothing, nothing but an empty word. And what is the true object of fame, that I should speak? But fame itself, as such, is nothing: nothing but a word. For by fame, I should never think that I was a man: nothing that I should be worthy of worship, nothing that I should be worthy of respect, nothing that I should be worthy of praise, but a man as any other. For so, when thou dost think that that man was worthy of praise, whose eye was open, whose tongue was loose, or whose lips were set so. For by these things is a man worthy of praise: nothing else. <BEGIN> On the passage of time, and the nature of time, as one universal and constant, and which, in respect to the number of its years, doth seem infinite; as if it were one continued and uninterrupted flow, in a constant motion; and which, in itself, hath no beginning or end, and which doth not cease to flow, or pass by.

Some do say, that the nature of time, is the same thing with the nature of eternity; for as eternity, doth not have any beginning or end, neither can it be measured or expressed in terms of any other things. For all the words and names we put to eternity, do but express only the idea of something infinite and endless, or unmeasurable and incomprehensible. But if, in speaking of eternity, we do use some of the names of finite things, such as hours, days, years, etc. it is not that the names themselves are infinite or unmeasurable; but that they are so applied, that they do express the true nature of those things, and that those things themselves do have the name or title, of the infinite or endless, in them. A woman, being taken with a passion, that she did not know herself, had in her hand a vessel of water, and, by her passion, did throw it out, so that all the water did run away. Now the woman, after this, did remember herself, and, being grieved for the loss of the water, she was in a great fear and dismay; for she said unto herself, That she could not get water again; but that the world would be dry, if she were not careful. She had been carried away with a passion, and by the same passion had lost that, which she could not get again; and so, she had been carried away again by the same passion, and had lost that, which she could not get again; and so it was with all her days. This parable, that women were carried away with their passions, and so they lost those things, which they could not get again, and could not recover them again. This parable is true, and it is a true parable, that there is a certain kind of madness, which is as hard to be cured, as a true madness of the mind; for she is carried away, and can carry away nothing. <BEGIN> On the nature of the universe
For a true understanding of any one thing, it is necessary that we should know the nature of all others. For that which is true of one part of the universe, must also be true of some other part of the same universe, that it may be either the same thing or different from it. That is, the difference must be some such thing, either a proper accident of it, or a proper form of it. That is to say, if a particular man should say that his body was not a body, his body was a body, but that a body was not his body; and so forth. That is to say, if a man should say that he had no head; a head he hath; but a head he had not, that he had a head. To have a head, and not a head, are two different things: as to have a head, and not a head, is one; and to have a head, and to have a head, is another. And if one should say that a man had a head, and yet that head was not his own, he would speak falsely. That is to say, the head is not that of that man; but that of a man of the race or gender of that man: <END>

<BEGIN> How to face death? and how to prepare yourself for death?
The great philosopher Epictetus says, “It is necessary not only to fear death, but also to hate and detest it.” Death is but a natural change, and a change from one state of things to another: it is necessary therefore to hate and detest death; because it is a change of a very different kind from that of the seasons or the year. The year cometh, the year goeth: but death, which cometh not, but doth never go, is a very different change from that of the year.
It is a common error, to think that it is hard to bear death; whereas in truth it is but a change of things: and the harder the thing, the more willing is nature to bear it. But the cause that the nature of man is so well adapted for it, that death is the very end of a life naturally lived, is that man is capable of being prepared for it. And this preparation is to be made in the understanding and imagination.
How is the understanding prepared for death? For the understanding is prepared for death, by having the memory of the death of other men, and the knowledge of the nature and the cause of death. For this doth prepare <END>

For rhetoric doth teach all the parts of oratory: but philosophy teacheth those that doth belong unto the true understanding and knowledge. And so the two may be well joined together: For they do agree in that which is essential unto both, that is, the true understanding. <BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless
Fame can be a curse in disguise. It is often associated with wealth and power, but it is not always the case. For instance, many famous people struggle financially, and their wealth is often used for selfish and unethical purposes.
Fame can also lead to a kind of psychological imbalance. It can make people feel like they are invincible and above criticism. They can become arrogant, and their behavior can become erratic. This can lead to a kind of isolation, where they are unable to relate to others, and their relationships with others suffer.
In addition, fame can be a source of anxiety. The pressure to constantly produce and perform is great. There is a lot of stress involved in maintaining a public image. The fear of losing fame and status is a powerful motivator. This anxiety can lead to burnout and depression.
Fame can also lead to a kind of disconnection from reality. It can make people feel like they are above the law and that they can do whatever they want without consequences. This can lead to a kind of moral decay.
Finally, fame can also lead to a kind of superficiality. It can make people focus on external appearances, and forget about the inner qualities that truly matter. They can lose sight of what is truly important, <END>

<BEGIN> On finding peace and contentment

It is not an easy matter to find peace and contentment, but I do most fervently pray and implore you, as for my own sake, so for theirs, to labour after these things, that it may be the case, as a general observation, that they be able to find some satisfaction in all circumstances. But when it comes to particular circumstances, that may be able to vex and trouble us, that we may be able to bear them with patience and peace of mind, that may be said, that we have truly found our peace. That which is in this world, that is able to trouble and vex us, is but a thing that is subject to our own will; and what we do, we must not suffer that thing to trouble us, but must strive against it.

<BEGIN> Endurance of pain is not always necessary or proper.
There are some particular kinds of pain, wherein the strength and endurance of the constitution is strained and tried. Some, for example, which arise from a great bodily change or alteration, such as the pain of the puerperal woman, or the pain of the woman who has given birth of a monster. Others, from some hurt or injury, such as the pain of a severe wound, or the pain of some disease, or the pain of the tooth. But these pains, though painful, are proper, and not dangerous to life. But some other kinds of pain, though not proper, and dangerous to life, yet are to be borne and endured. The pain of a murderer's sword, for example; or the pain of a robber's dagger, or the pain of a wild beast's sting. These pains are dangerous to life; and a man ought not to endure them. For if he can help it, he ought not to suffer any thing. For the very idea of endurance, is nothing more, than that some one thing must suffer. <BEGIN> On the shortness of life.
It is the greatest part of the world that is in a state of perpetual change: it is the greatest part of the world that is in a state of perpetual motion: and it is the greatest part of the world that is in a state of perpetual motion, because there is nothing that is not constantly subject to the operation of some agent. This is the general property of all things that exist. Things are all subject to operation, or rather they are all subject to operation of some kind, in some way, or by some means.
They that are of a philosophical temper, and who are well conversant with themselves, and with those that are with them, cannot but be sensible, that the universe is very short and very narrow: it is very narrow and short, in respect of the space of time which it occupyeth; and it is short and narrow in respect of the extent and bulk of things that are in it. And therefore those that are of a philosophical temper, and who are well conversant with themselves, and with those that are with them, can only wish and pray for the better part of the world, and for the better part of themselves, and for the better part of that which is with them.

<BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless to you
As the world sees me, I am the king of kings.
To me, however, I am no king at all.
I am the lowliest of servants, the most vile and abominable.
My eyes, which look out to the world, are blind; my eyes that look inwards are not able to see.
The world sees me; I see not.
The world is my judge, but I know not what it doth judge.
The world is the fountain of all justice, but I am not a part of it.
I am but a poor creature, without any power, without any riches, without any reputation;
I am a stranger and an outcast from all the world;
I am an unworthy wretch, and a miserable object to be looked upon, and a loathsome thing to be smelled;
I am but a drop in the ocean, a speck upon the sand;
I am nothing, and nothing at all, in the eyes of the world.

<BEGIN> On finding peace, or tranquility in a woman.

If any one would give the means, whereby a woman, either a matron or a maid, may find herself, and her spirit, at peace; let him do it. But to be contented, and at ease, is the fruit of the contemplation of her true nature, and the understanding of the nature of her passions, and the works of her soul.

There is not so much to be desired as to be happy, and to be at peace. This is the end of all desires; this is the end of all affections; this is the end of all worldly cares and troubles: This is that which is not a thing to be desired, or to be affected by, but to be embraced. To embrace and to love, that is true happiness. For if a man love the truth, and the right understanding, and be at peace; how happy must he be? How happy must the man be, that hath the truth in his hand, and in his understanding: And how happy shall the man be, that is truly happy and at peace.

<BEGIN> On the passage of time in the natural world
Natural time is a relative concept that has undergone many transformations and changes throughout the ages. The earliest chronicles and records of time keepers date back to the Babylonians, who around 2000 BC were the first to divide the year into 12 months. The Egyptians were the first to divide the year into 365 days, and the Babylonians were the first to divide the year into 360 days.
In the Babylonian calendar, the year was divided into 12 months, with the first month, Nisanu, being the beginning of the new year. The Babylonians also had a system of counting days, which was based on the number of the moon's phases. Each month was associated with a particular animal, a particular element, and a particular color.
The Babylonians also divided the year into 12 different parts, each of which had its own name. These parts were based on the lunar cycles, with the first part beginning on the 1st of Nisanu, the first of the new year, and ending on the 29th of Tammuz, the 10th month of the Babylonian calendar. The parts were named after the animals that were associated with each of them, such as the first part, which <END>

But when they would speak, they either say or think that which they are not able to say or to think. Or they say or think that which is not good.
But that which is good, is that which is done, by the power and grace of God. For this reason is it, that the silent ones are blessed withal.

<BEGIN> Endurance of pain and suffering
Endurance of pain and suffering is an aspect of the Christian life and one of the ways in which Christians live in obedience to the Gospel. St. Paul and other writers of the New Testament speak of it, as also the Church Fathers, and the blessed Martyrs. It is not less pertinent unto Christians, even to this present day, forasmuch as that, as it were, the natural temper of man is such, that it is easy for men, especially those of a seditious disposition, to take flight from their duty, and to flout against the discipline and obedience required of them. The only end of endurance of pain and suffering, is to get a share in that eternal and happy life of the saints. It is not, to suffer patiently for their own sake, but because the pain and suffering, doth but serve for the reward. If this be not so, it will follow that the suffering and pain is for itself, and is not but a means unto the end. But this, the nature of a saint is, that they suffer and do patiently endure. <BEGIN> On the shortness of life. The time of death is fixed; there are certain particular times of the year and of the seasons in which the natural course of all things is altered; and this course of all things is itself to be altered by death, which is to be thought of as a change in the nature and the course of all things.
Of all things whatsoever, death is to be thought of first; and therefore also of the rest of all things; for it is the proper end of all things whatsoever, as well of things natural and created as things natural and spiritual; and therefore it is to be considered of first; and all things else are to be considered of as coming to this end; and as all things come to this end, all things must come to this end.
Of all things whatsoever, death is the proper end; as indeed is also the proper end of the whole world; that is to be destroyed. And that is to be destroyed, that there be no more of anything. And of this, the death of a man is the proper sign; that is to be destroyed of the body of a man.

H. On the Nature of the Universe
Tis not that they are all created, only in one of them is that which is most worthy of remembrance; but to that which is created is to be ascribed the praise of the whole.

And therefore let this be observed; that if we regard not any other, but only the nature of the Universe, there is a whole universe, that is to say, the whole World; in which every particular thing, or creature, hath a nature and essence.

Hence it followeth, that those things are as it were to be considered, which are called things; and what they are, and what they be, and what they are for; but all things in the whole Universe, and all things in all things, are to be considered together.

<BEGIN> How to face death
When we say that man's life is long and easy to live, we mean that it is short compared with the duration of the universe. But when we say that a man's death is easy to die, we mean that his death is a matter of little or no importance, because it is not much matter whether a man die early or late. In order to get rid of all fear of death, we must put the soul and spirit in a wayward and vain conceit and imagination, that it is not really a man that dies, but only a body. For of all the things that happen, death is the only thing that is truly terrible; and it is that of itself which is dreadful, not because of what it brings to pass, but because of the fear of it; for it is of that fear that the soul and spirit must be freed.

For that which makes death a fearful thing is the expectation of another life. But the soul that is freed from this expectation, that fears nothing, nor is afraid of anything, will find that she is not afraid of death.

<BEGIN> The duty of a leader, in any capacity, is to see that justice is done. In other words, the leader’s duty is to see that the law, or that moral system which is considered universal, is observed and obeyed. Now, such a system, I believe, does not exist; for I have never heard of any such thing as a universal moral system, which is universally acknowledged and obeyed, both by all nations, and by all men. But then, says one, what is the moral system that you speak of? For so many nations, and so many different nations, there are so many different moral systems and religious systems; and there are so many contradictions and inconsistencies, that it is impossible for any such universal moral system to exist.

To this, I answer, that it is possible. For I believe that there are certain principles and maxims, that are so generally agreed upon by all rational men, that they must be considered universal. Such principles and maxims are, the principles of justice, of morality, of truth, and of religion.

<BEGIN> On logic and reason; or, The art of reasoning well
by Thomas Wilson

Dedications.

Dedication to the Reader

Hath the writer of this discourse any other object or design, other than the pure and true explication of the matter in hand, as hath been already done? No; but only to help the mind and imagination to exercise and improve itself upon the matter, that is, the art of reasoning; for which there is a certain and proper kind of learning, and skill, and habit, whereby a man may be enabled to deal with reason and argument, as with any other art or skill. And as it is with any other art, so also with this: so soon as a man hath learned the matter, and the form of it, he must exercise it in practice, if he would be any way wise.

Dedication to the Reader

If the reader of these books, were of that modest and humble sort, that doth desire to be in good order, and in the right way with himself, and with others, then I pray that he may be so good and modest, as not to suppose that the art of reasoning is any thing strange or new; but to be as sensible, as is necessary, and reasonable.

<BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless
Fame is a fleeting thing, a thing of the air, which doth soon vanish and pass away, leaving nothing in its stead but memory, which doth in time decay. It doth depend entirely upon the good opinion of others, which is subject to all sorts of changes, and is not fixed.

This is the way with all things, which are subject to change and decay. A thing that is now of great importance, and is highly valued, is soon forgotten. A thing which is now of small importance, and is highly valued, soon ceases to be.

Fame, as I said, doth depend entirely upon the good opinion of others, which is subject to all sorts of changes, and is not fixed. A man that hath no other aim or desire, but to be loved, and to be admired, and to be envied, shall be most unhappy. For he shall never be able to satisfy himself. A man that is contented and at ease, and is not troubled with any cares or anxieties, shall be most happy.

Now, for all those that are contented and at ease, I would they should not be troubled, and should not be vexed, with any care or anxiety. For that doth make <END>

<BEGIN> On finding peace of mind: A meditation.
Meditation is a more powerful remedy than any other against those evils that afflict us; and more effectual than any other, in respect of its being of a more easy and simple kind.

For as for all those things that either by themselves or by their association, are able to cause us to be vexed and disturbed, they all are nothing, and as nothing, they are soon forgotten: for when we have once thought on them, and laid them to heart, we shall presently be free from them.

And this also we may reasonably say, that the very thing that causes trouble, is that very thing, which, if properly considered and examined, can cause no trouble; and that, if once it be considered, and set to right, all other things can be put in good order.

For what is it that troubles us? What is it that offends? Is it not pride, ambition, avarice, revenge, anger, or some other such passion? Which of these, I pray, let us once and for all consider and examine, and put them to right, that all the rest of the things in the world, may be put in good order.

<BEGIN> On the passage of time
As the sun moves among the stars, as a wheel turning among the wheels, the stars are seen to change their order: and of them, some appear to be nearer or farther than they were; and their brightness or darkness is altered: which if the heavens had been fixed, would not have been. But because they are not fixed, it is proper, that they should have the place and the order, according to the time of the year, or according to the time of day; and so also of the planets and of the stars that are in the firmament. And it is proper that they should move among themselves in such a manner, that their motion, according to their place and order, according to the time, doth not appear as it did the day before, or the day before that. For if they should always remain in the same place, it would be as if the world was immovable; which is not so; but rather that it is a machine, which moves and is moved, according as it is disposed, by God, for His own proper ends and purposes.

<BEGIN> Endurance of pain
The Stoics called endurance of pain an exercise of virtue; and they showed themselves by this action worthy of praise, and deserving of all admiration. It was a true exercise of a good spirit; and those that practiced it, did manifestly prove themselves men of sound judgment, and men that were capable of the true exercise of reason, and of the true exercise of the virtues.
How to describe such endurance and constancy, as that it did not in the least abate, even when the very soul, that bore the pain, was rent and torn asunder, both body and soul? What language could we use, that might be sufficient to describe such an act of endurance? What words or expressions, what phrases or sentences, that might be adequate to express such an act? Is not it that very act of endurance, that is truly worthy of admiration, and deserving of all praise? Is it not that very act, which we call endurance of pain? Let us therefore praise it, and say that it is a truly excellent exercise of virtue, and that it is a most noble and excellent action; that it is a thing truly worthy of our admiration; that it is a true and proper exercise of a good spirit. 1

<BEGIN> On the nature of the universe, a philosophical question
This work is not a work of fiction. As an excerpt from an early Stoic dialogue, it is the original source of the phrase: "Nature is a hard mistress." It is also the earliest known example of the universe as the totality of all that is. Thus the universe is not only a part of nature, but it also is the totality of nature. As such, it is the very essence of nature. If the universe is a hard mistress, that is to say, it is not kind towards her who will not submit to her laws and principles, and will not accept her grace, or her assistance.... By the universal nature, that is, by the nature which is common to all things. But also of the natural reason, which is the nature of reason itself. And so, by the nature of nature, that is, by nature itself. This is a kind of true unity. For if the universe were a unity, a one in a way of things, this would be a kind of unity, or unity of a certain sort. <BEGIN> How to face death
How to face death
It is very difficult to face death with courage and courage. This is not an easy thing. This is very much painful. To face death is to face the great and mighty death itself.
The wise and just men also, who have passed by, they did not suffer death, but it suffered them, and in that respect, they are most happy.
For those who are worthy of a good soul and a good disposition, they did not fear death, but on the contrary they were most bold and valiant, and with a good cheer and a happy heart, they did die. The same also was with those who were worthy of a good reputation and a good fame.
That we may have courage and fortitude, and be not afraid of death, and that we may also have a good conscience and a pure mind, and that we may always be obedient to God and his commandments, and that we may be just and temperate in all our actions, and that we may be worthy of our own dignity and of the dignity of all other men. <BEGIN> The duty of a leader, in particular, is to keep his heart fixed upon the right and true object; which is, according to the scripture, the glory of God. The glory of God is to do God’s will. <BEGIN> On logic and reason
The practice of a philosopher, and a man of philosophy, doth consist in a perpetual motion and discourse. This perpetual motion and discourse is one and the same with reason; for in all these, the mind is moved by itself. The practice of a philosopher, is to understand and discourse upon nature: to see to it, that all things be well done and disposed of. The practice of a man, of the common sort, is to make the most of himself; to do that which is convenient and commodious, and to take heed of the rules of the common art. And all men do take heed of their own rules and common rules. They do therefore all one, in this; that all men do take heed of their own rules. And they all agree in this, that a man should always follow and do that, which is convenient and commodious. This is that, which is called the rule of nature.
In a word, all the things of the world are to be understood and taken in hand; but by reason only and by understanding, not by imagination or fancy.

<BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless?
Fame is often considered to be the most desirable and most coveted thing that can happen to a man. It is often said that when a man is famous, he is happy and contented. But the truth is that fame is often meaningless. The reason for this is that the object of fame, which is a man himself, is often devoid of all good qualities. And the object of his fame, which is his reputation, is a mere shadow of the true self of the man, and not a true self at all.
This is what the Buddha said in the Dhammapada. For this reason we must always remember to be mindful and cautious, and not to let ourselves be led astray by the fleeting objects of the world, and to make a distinction between the true self and the false self.
Fame is also the object of many other creatures. But they too are often devoid of good qualities. And their object of fame, their reputation, is also but a mere shadow of the true self of the man. The true self, however, is one and only, and cannot be divided.
Therefore let us always remember that true fame and honor is the one which is acquired by the practice of virtue, and the performance of good actions. Let us always <END>

It was an ancient custom of the Romans to go to their houses every day after a certain hour in the morning, and not to return again for a long while; so as that all their business was performed within a very short time. <BEGIN> On finding peace and happiness in all that is done and suffered.
How often have men found that whatever was once performed or suffered, is now forgotten. And that it is not even worthy of a moment's reflection; how little soever it is of itself. And yet what is the reason of this? Is it that they are not able to see the happiness, peace, and contentment, that can be in the very act itself? Is it, that the memory of their sorrow or grief, is too deeply impressed upon their minds? Or that their understanding is too darkened by some cloud or prejudice; and therefore doth not clearly see, what is good and right in itself, and in other men?
Consider it therefore, O thou, who dost desire to be happy, that the very thing which thou sufferest or doest, is itself the cause of that happiness or peace, which thou desirest; and that thou canst not do any thing, without happiness; and that thou canst not do any thing, but to the best of thy power: Thou must therefore be content, that whatever thou dost do, or whatsoever thou sufferest, it shall be the best that can be done, or that can be suffered; and that thou canst not do any thing, <END>

<BEGIN> On the passage of time in the solar system; on the periods of the planets.
## On the passage of time in the solar system
We are to observe that the periods of the planets are not always equal. The sun is not always equal in his motions, nor are the planets always equal in theirs. For the sun is a globe, and doth therefore carry with him an unequal velocity and speed, as well in his rotation about his axis, as in his circular motion about the earth. And as the planets are also a multitude of bodies, which do move and runne with their several velocities, and in their circular motions about their axes and the earth, the times of their revolution shall not be the same in respect of their distances. The sun and the earth are the nearest and most adjoining, the other planets being more remote and separated; and therefore their times of revolution shall differ according to their distances from the sun.
And so also in the periods of the planets, for the earth and the moon, though they be nearest to one another, do carry on the motions, as if they were more remote; and their periods of revolution are not the same, as if they were not more remote. For the earth, in the course of one day, doth pass by the same sun <END>

<BEGIN> On the nature of the universe and its motion. An essay by the Rev. Dr. William Paley.

In that general sense, the universe is a great body, of which this world is one part, and of which this part is an aggregate of things, and a collection of bodies, and a mixture of all kinds of things, and a concourse of all kinds of things.

In this view, it is evident, that it is impossible, but that there is a kind of natural government over the world, or rather, a kind of natural law, that governs all things, and regulates their motions. For this is the natural consequence of all things having one common matter, and being all part of the same universe. And what is not true of other particular bodies, must also be true of this universal body; that is, it must have a natural and proper motion.

This, therefore, is the true nature of the universe; that it is a body, which is governed by some natural law or rule; and that this rule must be of that nature, which is natural and proper to the universe. For all things, whether they be particular bodies, or an universal body, must all of them be governed by that one true and universal law, that governs all things.

<BEGIN> Endurance of pain can vary widely among individuals. Factors that may influence an individual's endurance of pain include genetic predisposition, emotional and psychological factors, and environmental and social factors.
Endurance of pain can also vary widely depending on the specific type and severity of the pain. For example, a mild pain that is associated with a common and harmless condition, such as a headache caused by tension or a cold, may be endured for a longer period of time than a more severe and potentially debilitating pain, such as a severe migraine or a chronic illness. Furthermore, an individual's ability to focus attention and manage distraction, as well as their ability to maintain motivation and engage in coping behaviors, can also influence their endurance of pain. Additional factors to consider are the individual's past experiences and memories, including experiences related to pain, and their social and cultural background. Understanding these factors can help healthcare professionals to provide individualized treatment and support to individuals with chronic pain. Effective management of pain is critical to improving quality of life, reducing suffering and disability, and promoting health and well-being.

<BEGIN> How to face death?
Death is one of the most dreaded and feared phenomena of human existence. The fear of death is natural, and its inevitability is inescapable. The question, however, that we need to answer is: how to face death?
The first step, which is not difficult, is to accept death. We should realize that death is natural and inevitable and that our life is but a fleeting moment. The fear of death must be removed and we should realize that our fear is based on a false assumption.

Facing death is not about fear of dying but about facing death head-on. It involves a willingness to let go and a acceptance of the inevitable. <BEGIN> On logic and reason. This is a very plain matter. All which is truly and properly called a reason or syllogism, is but a part of a greater whole. It is a small part of that one, which is properly called a demonstration; and that again is part of a greater, that is properly called an argument, or proof.
In logic and rhetoric, there are three parts of speech: the simple, the compound, and the complex. Of these, the first is one simple sound, or sound alone; the second is one sound of two, and of two different things; and the third is one of three, and of three different things.
The simple sound is one of one single thing. The compound sound is of one thing, and another: as two or more. The complex sound is of one thing, and two or three other things.
These three sounds, therefore, are all of one substance, and of the same kind; but are, in respect of the number of things, different.
The simple sound is one; the compound is two; and the complex is three.
The simple is, as it were, of one colour, the compound of two colours; and the complex of three.

<BEGIN> On logic and reason.
In the natural world, all things that are reasonable are found; in the world of men, those which are unreasonable. The latter, however, do not only exist, but are also very well adapted to their proper ends; and in proportion as they are unreasonable, so are their proper ends unreasonable. And when, therefore, one must choose between those two things, to use reason or to use an unreasonable thing, it is better to use reason; not only because there are those which are unreasonable, but because of the very nature and constitution of the mind, that it can never be reasonable. (c)
The only thing, however, which is unreasonable, is that which is unreasonable itself. All things which are reasonable are, in fact, reasonable, and in a certain sense they are all of them rational. And such is the very nature of reason itself, that it can never be unreasonable.
All rational things are reasonable. All unreasonable things are also unreasonable. But that which is neither reasonable nor unreasonable, cannot exist.
(c) This is a passage from a dialogue by Cicero. The reasonings and arguments presented in the text are generally attributed to him.

<BEGIN> Endurance of pain and suffering, in the hope of a better life, as it is called. What is it that the soul of a man is, that he can endure pain, and yet can still hope to be better? Is it the pain itself that can endure, or the hope itself that can endure? or is it the understanding and the memory, that can endure the pain and hope, and yet not be destroyed?

One must be able to endure pain, that is, to endure the afflictions of life, and yet not be destroyed by them. One must also be able to endure hope, and yet not be destroyed by it. For if one can endure hope, then he cannot be destroyed by it; but if he is destroyed by hope, then he cannot endure it.

There are two kinds of endurance: one that is natural and ordinary, and the other that is extraordinary and uncommon.

The first kind is natural and ordinary, because it is such as happens of itself and by nature, and is not forced or coerced by any external thing. For example, a man can endure his own pain and suffering, because it is his own, and is a part of his own constitution; but it is not the pain and suffering of the external world that he can endure.

<BEGIN> On the nature of the universe.  This is an argument drawn from the nature of things: the first question, whether the world be finite or infinite, is this, whether the things that are, and the things that are not, be finite or infinite: for these two kinds of things only is it possible, either to speak of their nature, or to make any comparison between them; either to speak of their nature, because they are such as to admit of comparisons, or to make any comparison, because it is necessary either to speak of their nature, or else to understand of something else that is not subject to comparison.  I. To be able to make any comparison;  To be such, as to admit of any comparison:  To be finite.  II. To be such, as to admit of any comparison:  To be infinite.  III. To be such, as to admit of no comparison:  To be finite, and not infinite:  To be a circle.  IV. To be such, as to admit of no comparison:  To be infinite, and not finite.  To be a sphere.  These are the four kinds of things that only are capable of being compared:  those which are finite, and finite, or both finite and infinite. <END>

<BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless. Famous people often experience existential dread. They are aware that they are not just ordinary people. This is not a bad thing. It is a good thing. They have access to great knowledge, great wisdom, and great creativity. And they have a lot of responsibility. They have a lot of influence. They can make a big difference in the world. The more they are aware of this, the more they can use their powers. And the more they can use their powers, the more they can achieve. And the more they can achieve, the more they can fulfill themselves. So why do we hate our own selves. This is the most difficult problem. We are all the same. We are all human beings. <BEGIN> On dealing with anger: A Stoic meditation
To deal well with anger, or with any other passion, is to beget in thy mind the right judgement, and to consider, that it is a thing not of itself, but is wrought out by the confluence of other causes and circumstances. Now thou mayest readily observe, how many causes there be which concur to produce this anger. But thou shalt not consider of all those, which thou canst not know. No, thou shalt only consider of those, which thou canst know: for this is the part of a man, that is worthy and wise.
To the man who has begun to reason: let this also be his conclusion, that his anger shall not last long, and shall soon pass over unto another: and that it is not the proper seat of this anger, that doth stir it up, and make it to persist. For many things do stir it up, and yet not properly, or according to their proper nature: as in the case of the lover, and the friend, or the servant, or the master: for these things are not proper to anger, but to some other passions; but yet do stir it up.
It is then that the wise man is able to be free from anger, <END>

<BEGIN> Why fame is meaningless

But, I know, many men would say, that if they were not known to all men, they would be no better men than other men. That is the height and perfection of their glory; to be known to all men, not for any virtue, but for their outward appearance and comely parts.

What doth Timothy know of the other Timothy? None at all, no more than what a blind man, or a drunken man, knoweth anything of another blind man, or drunken man.

<BEGIN> On finding peace and contentment, the great philosopher Epicurus said, that his pleasure was to live; that he had a great and earnest desire to be happy and contented; and that the cause of his happiness and contentment was his own good disposition, his constant meditation, and his conversation with good and virtuous men.

The cause of his happiness and contentment, then, was his own good disposition. How then can it be that many of us, who are much more contented than many of our forefathers, should complain so much of their own happiness? The cause is not their happiness, but their discontent; which comes either from their own bad disposition, or from the corrupt nature of the world. Let us, then, seek to get rid of our discontent, as soon as possible, either by improving our own disposition, or by changing our place, and removing ourselves from the corrupt influences of the world. Let us, therefore, not only be contented, but let us also be happy, and that by a sincere and hearty desire after happiness and contentment. (From the Stoic)

I say to thee, that it was many, many, many kinds of things, but I say to thee, that it was, one kind of thing; and that one kind of thing is, that it was things of time: but what are things of time? Things of time, are those which are not of eternity. Things of eternity, are those which have no end: things of time, are those which are end-ed; things of eternity, are those which are endless. <BEGIN> The virtue of silence is the one that is most difficult for a man to keep. For generally men are lovers of words, and very fond of speaking, and in the practice of their speaking, they find a great delight. In all other cases, indeed, men are governed by reason and virtue, and yet they cannot do it in their speaking. For they would rather do a wrong thing, than not to speak at all, and therefore they are often in a manner undone, either by the wrongness of their words, or by the folly, or rashness, and impiety, and many other things. In the case of the Stoics, however, this is not so. For they also do speak, but they are so much bound up in the fear of God, that they do not speak at all, unless it be upon very great occasions. But even then, if it be not for the public good, they would be more disposed to keep silence, than to utter words.
